revision.text:
{{Year box}} '''1826 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * 30 June — [[Jem Ward]] retains his English Championship title when he defeats Phil Sampson in ten rounds at Norwich.<ref>[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/ward-j.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – Jem Ward]. Retrieved on 6 November 2009.</ref>
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * Inter-county cricket flourishes again, mainly through the efforts of the [[Sussex county cricket teams|Sussex county organisation]] based on the Midhurst club. Sussex plays matches against [[Kent county cricket teams|Kent]] and a combined Hampshire/Surrey team. * The pavilion at [[Lord's Cricket Ground]] has been rebuilt following the fire in July 1825. From this time on, cricket records are more certain and will become increasingly so as scorecard data increases (e.g., to include the name of the bowler when a catch is taken) and standards of scoring become widely accepted. * 24, 25 and 26 July – Yorkshire's first great player [[Tom Marsden]] scores 227 for [[Sheffield Cricket Club|Sheffield]] and [[Leicestershire and Rutland Cricket Club|Leicester]] v [[Nottingham Cricket Club|Nottingham]] at the [[Darnall New Ground]] in Sheffield. This score beats the 167 scored by [[James Aylward (cricketer)|James Aylward]] in 1777 and is the new individual record for [[first-class cricket]].<ref>On the basis that William Ward's score of 278 in 1820 is not universally recognised as first-class.</ref> * 31 December — death of [[John Small (cricketer)|John Small]], the great [[Hambledon Club|Hambledon]] batsman '''England''' * Most runs – [[Tom Marsden]] 227 @ 227.00 (HS 227: he had just the one first-class innings) * Most wickets – [[William Lillywhite]] 27 (BB 9–?)
==[[Horse racing]]== '''England''' * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Problem (horse)|Problem]] * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – Dervise * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Lap-dog]] * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – Lilias * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – [[Tarrare (horse)|Tarrare]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Sports by year to 1850}}
[[Category:Sports by year|1826]] [[Category:1826 in sports| ]]

{{Year box}} [[Image:Melbourne cup 1881.jpg|thumb|400px|right|Engraving of the finish line at the 1881 [[Melbourne Cup]]]] '''1881 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sports.
==[[American football]]== '''College championship''' * [[NCAA Division I FBS National Football Championship|College football national championship]] – [[Yale Bulldogs]] '''Events''' * [[1881 Michigan Wolverines football team|Michigan Wolverines]] is the first "western" team to travel east and play against the established teams at [[Harvard Crimson football|Harvard Crimson]], [[Yale Bulldogs football|Yale Bulldogs]] and [[Princeton Tigers football|Princeton Tigers]].
==[[Association football]]== '''England''' * [[1881 FA Cup Final|FA Cup final]] – [[Old Carthusians F.C.|Old Carthusians]] 3–0 [[Old Etonians F.C.|Old Etonians]] at [[The Oval]] in the last final to be played between two southern amateur sides. * [[Blackburn Rovers]] and [[Bolton Wanderers]] both change their venues to enclosed grounds where gate money can be charged, an increasing practice among clubs that are openly (or otherwise) professional. * [[Preston North End]] is founded and plays from the start at [[Deepdale]], which holds the world record for the length of time a venue has been in continuous use by one major league club.<ref>Note that [[Bramall Lane]] is actually the oldest professional football venue but it was not adopted by [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]] until 1889.</ref> * [[Burnley FC]] founded as Burnley Rovers RUFC which decides in May 1882 to switch codes. The Rovers suffix is dropped two years later and the club renamed as Burnley AFC. * [[Newcastle United]], which has a complicated early history, is founded as Stanley FC by a cricket club in the Byker area of Newcastle. '''France''' * Foundation of [[FC Girondins de Bordeaux]]. '''Ireland''' * [[Moyola Park F.C.]] wins the inaugural [[Irish Cup|Irish Cup final]] '''Scotland''' * 12 March — [[Andrew Watson (footballer, born 1856)|Andrew Watson]] makes his [[Scotland national football team|Scotland]] debut, becoming the world's first black international [[football (soccer)|football]] player * [[1881 Scottish Cup Final|Scottish Cup final]] – [[Queen's Park F.C.|Queen's Park]] 3–1 [[Dumbarton F.C.|Dumbarton]] at [[Hampden Park (1873–83)|Hampden Park]] (replay after Dumbarton protests about the original match which Queen's Park has won 2–1)
==[[Baseball]]== '''National championship''' * [[National League]] champions – [[Chicago White Stockings (1870–89)|Chicago White Stockings]] '''Events''' * Detroit replaces Cincinnati leaving Cleveland and Providence the southerly cities on the [[National League]] circuit. Four others lie on the northerly rail line from stalwart Chicago to stalwart Boston: Detroit, Buffalo, Troy, and Worcester. * In autumn, for the first time, all eight National League clubs prepare to continue next season.
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * [[Paddy Ryan]] takes part in a number of exhibition bouts but does not defend his Heavyweight Championship of America title.<ref name="PR">[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/ryan-p.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – Paddy Ryan]. Retrieved on 12 November 2009.</ref> * [[John L. Sullivan]] continues his rise to the championship with a series of knockout victories, none of them lasting longer than eight rounds.<ref name="JLS">[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/sully.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – John L Sullivan]. Retrieved on 12 November 2009.</ref>
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * [[Lancashire County Cricket Club]] wins its first outright title. At the end of the season, an English team led by [[Alfred Shaw]] goes to Australia for the [[English cricket team in Australia in 1881–82|1881–82 Test series]]. '''England''' * [[Champion County]]<ref>A semi-official seasonal title proclaimed by media consensus prior to December 1889 when the official County Championship is constituted.</ref> – [[Lancashire County Cricket Club|Lancashire]] * Most runs – [[A. N. Hornby]] 1,534 @ 40.36 (HS 188) * Most wickets – [[Ted Peate]] 173 @ 12.68 (BB 8–30) '''Australia''' * Most runs – [[Tom Horan]] 318 @ 35.33 (HS 113) * Most wickets – [[Edwin Evans (cricketer)|Edwin Evans]] 32 @ 11.25 (BB 5–34)
==[[Golf]]== '''Major tournaments''' * [[1881 Open Championship|British Open]] – [[Bob Ferguson (golfer)|Bob Ferguson]]
==[[Gymnastics]]== '''Events''' * 23 July — the ''[[Federation Internationale de Gymnastique]]'', the world's oldest international sport federation, is founded.
==[[Horse racing]]== '''England''' * [[1881 Grand National|Grand National]] – Woodbrook * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – Thebais * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Peregrine (horse)|Peregrine]] * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Iroquois (horse)|Iroquois]] * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – Thebais * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – [[Iroquois (horse)|Iroquois]] '''Australia''' * [[Melbourne Cup]] – Zulu '''Canada''' * [[Queen's Plate]] – Vice Chancellor '''Ireland''' * [[Irish Grand National]] – Antoinette * [[Irish Derby Stakes]] – Master Ned '''USA''' * [[1881 Kentucky Derby|Kentucky Derby]] – [[Hindoo (horse)|Hindoo]] * [[Preakness Stakes]] – Saunterer * [[Belmont Stakes]] – Saunterer
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * 8 April — [[Oxford University Boat Club|Oxford]] wins the 38th [[The Boat Race 1881|Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]]
==[[Rugby football]]== '''Events''' * [[Wales national rugby union team|Wales]] plays its first international match but is well beaten by [[England national rugby union team|England]]
==[[Tennis]]== '''England''' * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon Men's Singles Championship]] – [[William Renshaw]] (GB) defeated [[John Hartley (tennis)|John Hartley]] (GB) 6–0 6–1 6–1 '''USA''' * First U.S. National Singles Championship, precursor of the [[US Open (tennis)|US Open]], won by [[Richard D. Sears]] (USA) who defeats [[William Glyn|William E. Glyn]] (USA) 6–0 6–3 6–2
'''World''' *The 5th pre-open era [[1881 Men's Tennis season]] gets underway 27 tournaments are staged this year from 23 May to 10 November.
==[[Yacht racing]]== '''America's Cup''' * The [[New York Yacht Club]] retains the [[America's Cup]] as [[Mischief (yacht)|''Mischief'']] defeats Canadian challenger ''Atalanta'', of the Bay of Quinte Yacht Club
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Sports by year 1851 – 1900}}
[[Category:Sports by year]] [[Category:1881 in sports| ]]

{{Year box}} '''1918 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
''Note — many sporting events did not take place because of [[World War I]] or the [[1918 flu pandemic]]''
==[[American football]]== '''College championship''' * [[NCAA Division I FBS National Football Championship|College football national championship]] – [[Pittsburgh Panthers]] '''Professional football''' * Most teams shut down due to World War I and the flu pandemic; those that continue play are forced to delay the start of play until the middle of October or later * [[Dayton Triangles]] defeat [[Detroit Heralds]], both of whom continue full operations despite war and flu, to establish themselves as strongest team in the nation * [[1918 Buffalo Niagaras season|Buffalo Niagaras]] sign [[Tommy Hughitt]] for play in a citywide league, establishing a trend of expansion of top-level professional competition outside Ohio
==[[Association football]]== '''Europe''' * There is no major football in Europe due to [[World War I]]
==[[Australian rules football]]== '''VFL Premiership''' * [[Sydney Swans|South Melbourne]] wins the 22nd [[Australian Football League|VFL]] Premiership beating [[Collingwood Football Club|Collingwood]] 9.8 (62) to 7.15 (57) in the [[1918 VFL Grand Final]]. '''[[South Australian National Football League|South Australian Football League]]''': * not contested due to World War I '''[[West Australian Football League]]''': * 21 September: [[East Fremantle Football Club|East Fremantle]] 11.8 (74) defeat [[East Perth Football Club|East Perth]] 8.5 (53) for their tenth WAFL premiership.
==[[Bandy]]== '''Sweden''' * [[Allsvenskan and Elitserien (bandy)|Championship final]] – [[IFK Uppsala Bandy|IFK Uppsala]] 4–1 [[IK Sirius]] (replay following 2–2 draw)
==[[Baseball]]== '''World Series''' * 5–11 September — [[1918 Boston Red Sox season|Boston Red Sox]] (AL) defeats [[1918 Chicago Cubs season|Chicago Cubs]] (NL) to win the [[1918 World Series]] by 4 games to 2 '''Events''' * [[Babe Ruth]] leads the [[American League]] in [[home run]]s for the first time, hitting 11 * 2 September — professional baseball is curtailed to accelerate mobilisation for war
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * No world titles change hands in 1918 but [[Jack Dempsey]], with a series of knockouts including one against [[Battling Levinsky]], is now the main challenger to [[Jess Willard]]. '''Lineal world champions'''<ref>[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/pastchp.htm Cyber Boxing Zone]</ref> * [[World Heavyweight Champion]]ship – [[Jess Willard]] * [[World Light Heavyweight Champion]]ship – [[Battling Levinsky]] * [[World Middleweight Champion]]ship – [[Mike O'Dowd]] * [[World Welterweight Champion]]ship – [[Ted "Kid" Lewis]] * [[World Lightweight Champion]]ship – [[Benny Leonard]] * [[World Featherweight Champion]]ship – [[Johnny Kilbane]] * [[World Bantamweight Champion]]ship – [[Pete Herman]] * [[World Flyweight Champion]]ship – [[Jimmy Wilde]]
==[[Canadian football]]== '''Grey Cup''' * not contested due to [[World War I]]
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * There is no [[first-class cricket]] in England, Australia, South Africa or the West Indies due to [[World War I]]. A number of first-class matches are arranged in New Zealand but are not part of any official competition. '''India''' * [[Bombay Quadrangular]] – [[Hindus cricket team|Hindus]] shared with [[Parsees cricket team|Parsees]] '''New Zealand''' * [[Plunket Shield]] – ''not contested''
==[[Cycling]]== '''[[List of Tour de France winners|Tour de France]]''' * not contested due to [[World War I]] '''[[List of Giro d'Italia general classification winners|Giro d'Italia]]''' * not contested due to [[World War I]]
==[[Figure skating]]== '''World Figure Skating Championships''' * not contested due to [[World War I]]
==[[Golf]]== '''Events''' * All major championships are cancelled due to [[World War I]]
==[[Horse racing]]== '''England''' * [[1918 Grand National|Grand National]] – ''not held due to [[World War I]]'' * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Ferry (horse)|Ferry]] * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Gainsborough (horse)|Gainsborough]] * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – Gainsborough * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – [[My Dear (British horse)|My Dear]] * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – Gainsborough '''Australia''' * [[Melbourne Cup]] – Night Watch '''Canada''' * [[Queen's Plate]] – Springside '''Ireland''' * [[Irish Grand National]] – Ballyboggan * [[Irish Derby Stakes]] – King John '''USA''' * [[1918 Kentucky Derby|Kentucky Derby]] – Exterminator * [[Preakness Stakes]] – ''not contested as a single race'' * [[Belmont Stakes]] – Johren
==[[Ice hockey]]== '''Stanley Cup''' * The temporary [[Toronto Arenas]] team defeats the [[1917–18 Montreal Canadiens season|Montreal Canadiens]] 10–7 to win the inaugural [[National Hockey League]] (NHL) championship * [[Vancouver Millionaires]] defeats [[Seattle Metropolitans]] 3–2 to win the [[Pacific Coast Hockey Association]] championship * 20–30 March — Toronto Arenas (NHL) defeats Vancouver Millionaires (PCHA) in the [[1918 Stanley Cup Finals]] by 3 games to 2 '''Events''' * 2 January — [[Montreal Wanderers]] disbands following destruction of its home venue by fire * [[Allan Cup]] is won by [[Kitchener Greenshirts]]
==[[Motor racing]]== '''Events''' * No major races are held anywhere worldwide due to [[World War I]]
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * [[The Boat Race|Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]] – not contested due to [[World War I]]
==[[Rugby league]]== '''England''' * All first-class competitions are cancelled due to [[World War I]] '''Australia''' * [[New South Wales Rugby League premiership|NSW Premiership]] – [[South Sydney Rabbitohs|South Sydney]] (outright winner) '''New Zealand''' *[[1918 New Zealand rugby league season]]
==[[Rugby union]]== '''Five Nations Championship''' * [[Six Nations Championship|Five Nations Championship]] series is not contested due to [[World War I]]
==[[Speed skating]]== '''Speed Skating World Championships''' * not contested due to [[World War I]]
==[[Tennis]]== '''Australia''' * [[List of Australian Open Men's Singles champions|Australian Men's Singles Championship]] – not contested due to [[World War I]] '''England''' * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon Men's Singles Championship]] – not contested due to [[World War I]] * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon Women's Singles Championship]] – not contested due to [[World War I]] '''France''' * [[List of French Open Men's Singles champions and finalists|French Men's Singles Championship]] – not contested due to [[World War I]] * [[List of French Open Women's Singles champions|French Women's Singles Championship]] – not contested due to [[World War I]] '''USA''' * [[US Open (tennis)|American Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Lindley Murray (tennis)|Lindley Murray]] (USA) defeats [[Bill Tilden]] (USA) 6–3 6–1 7–5 * [[US Open (tennis)|American Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Molla Bjurstedt Mallory]] (Norway) defeats [[Eleanor E. Goss]] (USA) 6–4 6–3 '''Davis Cup''' * 1918 International Lawn Tennis Challenge – ''not contested''
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Sports by year 1901 – 1950}}
[[Category:Sports by year]] [[Category:1918 in sports| ]]

{{Year box}} '''1923 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==[[American football]]== '''NFL championship''' * [[1923 Canton Bulldogs season|Canton Bulldogs]] '''College championship''' * [[Illinois Fighting Illini]] – [[college football]] national championship
==[[Association football]]== '''Bulgaria''' * Formation of the [[Bulgarian Football Union]] (BFU) '''England''' * [[1922–23 Football League|The Football League]] – [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] 60 points, [[Sunderland FC|Sunderland]] 54, [[Huddersfield Town]] 53, [[Newcastle United]] 48, [[Everton FC|Everton]] 47, [[Aston Villa]] 46 * [[1923 FA Cup Final|FA Cup final]] – [[Bolton Wanderers]] 2–0 [[West Ham United]] at [[Wembley Stadium (1924)|Empire Stadium, Wembley, London]]. The match, known as the "[[White Horse Final]]", is the inaugural Wembley final. * The [[Football League Third Division North|Third Division North]] expands from 20 to 22 clubs, bringing the total number of [[Football League]] clubs to 88. With [[Stalybridge Celtic]] expelled, the new clubs are [[Doncaster Rovers]], [[New Brighton A.F.C.|New Brighton]] (1923–1951) and [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|AFC Bournemouth]]. '''Germany''' * [[List of German football champions|National Championship]] – [[Hamburger SV]] 3–0 [[Union Oberschöneweide]] at Berlin '''Romania''' * [[Rapid Bucureşti]] is founded under the name "Cultural and Sporting Association CFR" (in Romanian: Asociatia culturala si sportiva C.F.R.) by a group of workers at the [[Grivita]] workshops. '''Spain''' * [[Celta de Vigo]] is founded after the merger of [[Real Vigo Sporting]] and [[Real Club Fortuna de Vigo]]. * Club Deportivo Villarreal, official founded on March 10, as predecessor for [[Villarreal CF]].{{citation needed|date =December 2016}} '''Turkey''' * Formation of the [[Turkish Football Federation]] (Türkiye Futbol Federasyonu or TFF) * [[Genclerbirligi S.K.|Genclerbirligi of Ankara]] officially founded on March 14.{{citation needed|date=December 2016}}
==[[Athletics (sport)|Athletics]]== '''Monaco''' * [[1923 Women's World Games|third Women's Olympiad]] in Monte Carlo
'''UK''' * [[1923 WAAA Championships|First British Track & Field championships for women]], London
'''US''' * [[1923 USA Outdoor Track and Field Championships|First American Track & Field championships for women]], New Jersey
==[[Australian rules football]]== '''[[1923 VFL season|VFL Premiership]]''' * 13 October – [[Essendon Football Club|Essendon]] wins the 27th [[Australian Football League|VFL]] Premiership, defeating [[Fitzroy Football Club|Fitzroy]] 8.15 (63) to 6.10 (46) at [[Melbourne Cricket Ground]] (MCG) in the [[1923 VFL Grand Final]].{{ref label|postponed|a|a}} '''[[South Australian National Football League|South Australian Football League]]''' * 29 September – [[Norwood Football Club|Norwood]] 9.12 (66) defeats [[North Adelaide Football Club|North Adelaide]] 6.4 (40) to win its second successive SAFL premiership * [[Magarey Medal]] won by [[Horrie Riley]] ([[Sturt Football Club|Sturt]]) '''[[1923 WAFL season|West Australian Football League]]''' * 6 October – [[East Perth Football Club|East Perth]] win its fifth consecutive premiership, beating [[East Fremantle Football Club|East Fremantle]] 9.9 (63) to 7.4 (46) * Sandover Medal won by [[William 'Digger' Thomas|“Digger” Thomas]] (East Perth)
==[[Bandy]]== '''Sweden''' * [[Swedish bandy champions|Championship final]] – [[Västerås SK Bandy|Västerås SK]] 2-1 [[IF Linnéa]]
==[[Baseball]]== '''World Series''' * 10–15 October — [[1923 New York Yankees season|New York Yankees]] (AL) defeats [[1923 New York Giants season|New York Giants]] (NL) to win the [[1923 World Series]] by 4 games to 2 '''Major League Baseball''' * 18 April — opening of the original [[Yankee Stadium (1923)|Yankee Stadium]] in the [[Bronx]] '''Negro League Baseball''' * The [[Eastern Colored League]] (ECL) plays its first season with six teams: [[Hilldale Daisies]], [[Brooklyn Royal Giants]], [[Cuban Stars (East)]], [[New York Lincoln Giants]], [[Atlantic City Bacharach Giants]], and [[Baltimore Black Sox]]. Hilldale wins the first pennant. Afterward the league votes for expansion to eight teams, accepting the [[Harrisburg Giants]] and the [[Washington Potomacs]]. * The [[Negro National League (the first)|Negro National League]] completes its fourth season with the [[Kansas City Monarchs]] winning their first pennant after three years of domination by [[Rube Foster]]'s [[Chicago American Giants]]. The other teams in the league are [[Indianapolis ABC's]], [[Detroit Stars]], [[St. Louis Stars (baseball)|St. Louis Stars]], [[Cuban Stars (West)]], [[Toledo Tigers]], and [[Milwaukee Bears]]. The Tigers and Bears disband during the season and three teams play under "associate" status for the remainder of the season: [[Cleveland Tate Stars]], [[Birmingham Black Barons]], and [[Memphis Red Sox]]. * [[Heavy Johnson|Oscar "Heavy" Johnson]] wins the NNL [[triple crown (baseball)|triple crown]], leading in [[batting average]], [[home run]]s, and [[runs batted in|RBI]], while [[Bullet Rogan|Wilbur "Bullet" Rogan]] leads in wins and strikeouts. [[Biz Mackey|Raleigh "Biz" Mackey]] is the batting leader in the ECL with [[Nip Winters|Jesse "Nip" Winters]] leading in most pitching categories. * There is no [[Negro League World Series|World Series]] between the two champions this year, owing to enmity between [[Rube Foster]] and the ECL president [[Ed Bolden]]
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * 18 June — [[Jimmy Wilde]]'s long reign as [[World Flyweight Champion]] ends when he is knocked out by Filipino [[Francisco Guilledo|Pancho Villa]] in the 7th round in New York City * 31 August — [[Harry Greb]], arguably the greatest-ever middleweight, takes the world title when he defeats [[Johnny Wilson (boxer)|Johnny Wilson]] over 15 rounds in New York City * 14 September — [[Jack Dempsey]] knocks out [[Luis Firpo]] in the second round of a sensational fight at the [[Polo Grounds]] in New York City to retain his [[World Heavyweight Champion]]ship title. '''Lineal world champions'''<ref>[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/pastchp.htm Cyber Boxing Zone]</ref> * [[World Heavyweight Champion]]ship – [[Jack Dempsey]] * [[World Light Heavyweight Champion]]ship – [[Battling Siki]] → [[Mike McTigue]] * [[World Middleweight Champion]]ship – [[Johnny Wilson (boxer)|Johnny Wilson]] → [[Harry Greb]] * [[World Welterweight Champion]]ship – [[Mickey Walker (boxer)|Mickey Walker]] * [[World Lightweight Champion]]ship – [[Benny Leonard]] * [[World Featherweight Champion]]ship – [[Johnny Kilbane]] → [[Eugene Criqui]] → [[Johnny Dundee]] * [[World Bantamweight Champion]]ship – [[Joe Lynch (boxer)|Joe Lynch]] * [[World Flyweight Champion]]ship – [[Jimmy Wilde]] → [[Francisco Guilledo|Pancho Villa]]
==[[Canadian football]]== '''Grey Cup''' * [[11th Grey Cup]] in the [[Canadian Football League]] – Queen's University 54–0 [[Saskatchewan Roughriders|Regina Roughriders]]
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * In a cool, damp English summer, a [[West Indian cricket team in England in 1923|West Indian team]] is on tour, winning six and losing seven [[first-class cricket|first-class]] matches. '''England''' * [[County Championship]] – [[Yorkshire County Cricket Club|Yorkshire]] * [[Minor Counties Championship]] – [[Buckinghamshire County Cricket Club|Buckinghamshire]] * Most runs – [[Patsy Hendren]] 2934 @ 77.21 (HS 200*) * Most wickets – [[Maurice Tate]] 219 @ 13.97 (BB 8–30) * [[Wisden Cricketers of the Year]] – [[Arthur Gilligan]], [[Roy Kilner]], [[George Macaulay]], [[Cec Parkin]], [[Maurice Tate]] '''Australia''' * [[Sheffield Shield]] – [[New South Wales cricket team|New South Wales]] * Most runs – [[Percy Chapman]] 782 @ 65.16 (HS 134*) * Most wickets – [[Arthur Mailey]] 55 @ 21.58 (BB 6–45) '''India''' * [[Bombay Quadrangular]] – [[Parsees cricket team|Parsees]] '''New Zealand''' * [[Plunket Shield]] – [[Canterbury cricket team|Canterbury]] '''South Africa''' * [[SuperSport Series|Currie Cup]] – not contested '''West Indies''' * [[Inter-Colonial Tournament]] – not contested
==[[Cycling]]== '''[[1923 Tour de France|Tour de France]]''' * [[Henri Pélissier]] (France) wins the 17th Tour de France '''[[1923 Giro d'Italia|Giro d'Italia]]''' * [[Costante Girardengo]] of Maino wins the eleventh Giro d'Italia
==[[Figure skating]]== '''World Figure Skating Championships''' * [[World Figure Skating Championships|World Men's Champion]] – [[Fritz Kachler]] (Austria) * [[World Figure Skating Championships|World Women's Champion]] – [[Herma Szabo]] (Austria) * [[World Figure Skating Championships|World Pairs Champions]] – Ludowika Jakobsson-Eilers and Walter Jakobsson (Finland)
==[[Golf]]== '''Major tournaments''' * [[1923 Open Championship|British Open]] – [[Arthur Havers]] * [[1923 U.S. Open (golf)|US Open]] – [[Bobby Jones (golfer)|Bobby Jones]] * [[1923 PGA Championship|USPGA Championship]] – [[Gene Sarazen]] '''Other tournaments''' * [[The Amateur Championship|British Amateur]] – [[Roger Wethered]] * [[United States Amateur Championship (men's golf)|US Amateur]] – [[Max R. Marston]]
==[[Horse racing]]== '''England''' * [[1923 Grand National|Grand National]] – Sergeant Murphy * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Tranquil (horse)|Tranquil]] * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Ellangowan (horse)|Ellangowan]] * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Papyrus (horse)|Papyrus]] * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – [[Brownhylda]] * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – [[Tranquil (horse)|Tranquil]] '''Australia''' * [[Melbourne Cup]] – Bitalli '''Canada''' * [[Queen's Plate]] – Flowerful '''France''' * [[Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe]] – [[Parth (horse)|Parth]] '''Ireland''' * [[Irish Grand National]] – Be Careful * [[Irish Derby Stakes]] – Waygood '''USA''' * [[1923 Kentucky Derby|Kentucky Derby]] – Zev * [[Preakness Stakes]] – Vigil * [[Belmont Stakes]] – Zev
==[[Ice hockey]]== '''Stanley Cup''' * 29–31 March — [[Ottawa Senators (original)|Ottawa Senators]] wins the [[Stanley Cup]] for the fifth time, defeating the [[Edmonton Eskimos]] by 2 games to 0 in the [[1923 Stanley Cup Finals]] '''Sweden''' * [[Klass I]], a professional ice hockey league in Sweden, as predecessor for [[Swedish Hockey League]], first officially game held on January 23.{{citation needed|date=December 2016}}
==[[Motorsport]]== {{main|1923 in motorsport|List of 1923 motorsport champions}}
==[[Multi-sport event]]s== '''Far Eastern Championship Games''' * The 6th [[1923 Far Eastern Championship Games|Far Eastern Championship Games]] is held at [[Osaka]], Japan.
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * 24 March — [[Oxford University Boat Club|Oxford]] wins the 75th [[The Boat Race|Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]]
==[[Rugby league]]== '''England''' * [[Rugby Football League Championship|Championship]] – [[Hull Kingston Rovers]] * [[Challenge Cup|Challenge Cup final]] – [[Leeds Rhinos|Leeds]] 28–3 [[Hull F.C.]] at [[Belle Vue (Wakefield)|Belle Vue, Wakefield]] * [[Rugby league county leagues|Lancashire League Championship]] – [[Wigan Warriors|Wigan]] * [[Rugby league county leagues|Yorkshire League Championship]] – [[Hull F.C.|Hull]] * [[RFL Lancashire Cup|Lancashire]] [[Rugby league county cups|County Cup]] – [[Wigan Warriors|Wigan]] 20–2 [[Leigh Centurions|Leigh]] * [[RFL Yorkshire Cup|Yorkshire]] [[Rugby league county cups|County Cup]] – [[York City Knights|York]] 5–0 [[Batley Bulldogs|Batley]] '''Australia''' * [[New South Wales Rugby League premiership|NSW Premiership]] – [[Sydney Roosters|Eastern Suburbs]] 15–12 [[South Sydney Rabbitohs|South Sydney]] (grand final)
==[[Rugby union]]== '''Five Nations Championship''' * 36th [[1923 Five Nations Championship|Five Nations Championship]] series is won by [[England national rugby union team|England]] who complete the [[Grand Slam (rugby union)|Grand Slam]].
==[[Speed skating]]== '''Speed Skating World Championships''' * [[1923 World Allround Speed Skating Championships|Men's All-round Champion]] – [[Clas Thunberg]] (Finland)
==[[Tennis]]== '''Australia''' * [[List of Australian Open Men's Singles champions|Australian Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Pat O'Hara Wood]] (Australia) defeats [[Bert St. John]] (Australia) 6–1 6–1 6–3 * [[List of Australian Open Women's Singles champions|Australian Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Margaret Molesworth]] (Australia) defeats [[Esna Boyd Robertson]] (Australia) 6–1 7–5 '''England''' * [[The Championships Wimbledon|Wimbledon Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Bill Johnston (tennis player)|Bill Johnston]] (USA) defeats [[Francis Hunter]] (USA) 6–0 6–3 6–1 * [[The Championships Wimbledon|Wimbledon Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Suzanne Lenglen]] (France) defeats [[Kitty McKane Godfree]] (Great Britain) 6–2 6–2 '''France''' * [[List of French Open Men's Singles champions and finalists|French Men's Singles Championship]] – [[François Blanchy]] (France) defeats [[Max Decugis]] (France) 1–6 6–2 6–0 6–2 * [[List of French Open Women's Singles champions|French Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Suzanne Lenglen]] (France) defeats [[Germaine Golding]] (France) 6–1 6–4 '''USA''' * [[List of US Open Men's Singles champions|American Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Bill Tilden]] (USA) defeats [[Bill Johnston (tennis player)|Bill Johnston]] (USA) 6–4 6–1 6–4 * [[List of US Open Women's Singles champions|American Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Helen Wills Moody]] (USA) defeats [[Molla Bjurstedt Mallory]] (Norway) 6–2 6–1 '''Davis Cup''' * [[1923 International Lawn Tennis Challenge]] – {{davis|USA|1912}} 4–1 {{davis|AUS}} at [[West Side Tennis Club]] (grass) [[New York City]], [[United States]]
==Notes== {{note label|postponed|a|a}}The Grand Final was postponed owing to heavy rain, creating the latest finish to a VFL/AFL season.
==References== {{Reflist}} {{Sports by year 1901 – 1950}}
[[Category:Sports by year]] [[Category:1923 in sports| ]]

{{Year box}} '''1941 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
Note — ''many sporting events did not take place because of [[World War II]]''
==[[American football]]== * [[Minnesota Golden Gophers]] – [[college football]] national champions. * [[1941 Chicago Bears season|Chicago Bears]] win 37–9 over [[1941 New York Giants season|New York Giants]] for the [[1941 NFL Championship Game|NFL]] championship. * Chicago Bears win only meeting vs. [[1941 Green Bay Packers season|Green Bay Packers]] in the playoffs. On January 23, 2011, they will meet again in the playoffs. It is the biggest rivalry in American football. * At a [[1941 Oklahoma City vs. Youngstown football game|college game]] in [[Youngstown, Ohio]], game officials use a [[penalty flag]] for the first time.
==[[Association football]]== * [[1940–41 La Liga|La Liga]] won by [[Atlético Madrid|Atlético Aviación]] * [[1941 German football championship|German football championship]] won by [[SK Rapid Wien]] * [[1940–41 Serie A|Serie A]] won by [[Bologna F.C. 1909|Bologna]] * [[1940–41 Primeira Divisão|Primeira Liga]] won by [[Sporting Clube de Portugal|Sporting CP]] *There is no major football competition in England, Scotland or France due to [[World War II]]. In England, [[Football League North and South|several regional leagues]] are played but statistics from these are not counted in players’ figures.
==[[Australian rules football]]== * [[1941 VFL season|Victorian Football League]] ** [[Melbourne Football Club|Melbourne]] wins the 45th VFL Premiership, beating [[Essendon Football Club|Essendon]] 19.13 (127) to 13.20 (98) in the [[1941 VFL Grand Final]] ** [[Brownlow Medal]] awarded to [[Norman Ware]] ([[Western Bulldogs|Footscray]]) * [[South Australian National Football League]]: ** 4 October: [[Norwood Football Club|Norwood]] 14.16 (100) beats [[Sturt Football Club|Sturt]] 10.11 (71) for their nineteenth premiership but first since 1929. * [[1941 WANFL season|Western Australian National Football League]]: ** 11 October: [[West Perth Football Club|West Perth]] 14.14 (98) beat [[East Fremantle Football Club|East Fremantle]] 10.17 (77) to win their eighth WANFL premiership.
==[[Baseball]]== * [[1941 New York Yankees season|New York Yankees]] win the [[1941 World Series|World Series]], beating [[1941 Brooklyn Dodgers season|Brooklyn Dodgers]] by 4 games to 1 * [[Ted Williams]] records a season [[batting average]] of .406; it is the last time any major leaguer will hit over .400 * [[Joe DiMaggio]]’s 56–game hitting streak (May 15 – July 16)
==[[Basketball]]== '''NBL Championship'''
*[[Oshkosh All-Stars]] win three games to none over the [[Sheboygan Redskins]]
'''Events''' * Ninth [[South American Basketball Championship 1941|South American Basketball Championship]] in [[Mendoza, Argentina|Mendoza]] is won by [[Argentina national basketball team|Argentina]].
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * The highlight of the year is the World Heavyweight title fight between two current world champions, Joe Louis and Billy Conn, won by Louis with a 13th round knockout. '''Lineal world champions'''<ref>[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/pastchp.htm Cyber Boxing Zone]</ref> * [[World Heavyweight Champion]]ship – [[Joe Louis]] * [[World Light Heavyweight Champion]]ship – [[Billy Conn]] * [[World Middleweight Champion]]ship – vacant → [[Tony Zale]] * [[World Welterweight Champion]]ship – [[Fritzie Zivic]] → [[Freddie "Red" Cochrane]] * [[World Lightweight Champion]]ship – [[Lew Jenkins]] → [[Sammy Angott]] * [[World Featherweight Champion]]ship – [[Harry Jeffra]] → [[Joey Archibald]] → [[Albert "Chalky" Wright]] * [[World Bantamweight Champion]]ship – [[Lou Salica]] * [[World Flyweight Champion]]ship – vacant
==[[Cricket]]== '''England and South Africa''' * There is no [[first-class cricket]] in England or South Africa due to [[World War II]]. '''India''' * [[Ranji Trophy]] – [[Maharashtra cricket team|Maharashtra]] defeats [[Madras cricket team|Madras]] by six wickets. * [[Bombay Quadrangular|Bombay Pentangular]] – [[Hindus cricket team|Hindus]] '''Australia''' * During the 1940–41 season, although the [[Sheffield Shield]] is not contested, a number of interstate cricket matches are played for patriotic funding. For the 1941–42 season, seven three-day interstate matches are scheduled but only one is played before the urgency of the [[Pacific War]] puts an end to Australian first-class cricket until November 1945. '''New Zealand and West Indies''' * New Zealand abandons the [[Plunket Shield]] for 1940–41 but here, and in the West Indies, a small number of first-class matches are arranged and played each season until after the war without being part of an official competition.
==[[Cycling]]== '''[[List of Tour de France winners|Tour de France]]''' * not contested due to [[World War II]] '''[[Giro d'Italia]]''' * not contested due to [[World War II]]
==[[Figure skating]]== '''World Figure Skating Championships''' * not contested due to [[World War II]]
==[[Golf]]== '''Men's professional''' * [[1941 Masters Tournament|Masters Tournament]] – [[Craig Wood (golfer)|Craig Wood]] * [[1941 U.S. Open (golf)|1941 U.S. Open]] – [[Craig Wood (golfer)|Craig Wood]] * [[1941 Open Championship|British Open]] – not played due to [[World War II]] * [[1941 PGA Championship|PGA Championship]] – [[Vic Ghezzi]] '''Men's amateur''' * [[The Amateur Championship|British Amateur]] – not played due to [[World War II]] * [[U.S. Amateur]] – [[Bud Ward]] '''Women's professional''' * [[Women's Western Open]] – [[Patty Berg]] * [[Titleholders Championship]] – [[Dorothy Kirby]]
==[[Horse racing]]== '''Steeplechases''' * [[Cheltenham Gold Cup]] – [[Poet Prince]] * [[1941 Grand National|Grand National]] – ''not held due to [[World War II]]'' '''Hurdle races''' * [[Champion Hurdle]] – [[Seneca (horse)|Seneca]] '''Flat races''' * Australia – [[Melbourne Cup]] won by [[Skipton (horse)|Skipton]] * Canada – [[Queen's Plate]] won by [[Budpath]] * France – [[Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe]] won by [[Le Pacha]] * Ireland – [[Irish Derby Stakes]] won by [[Sol Oriens]] * [[Triple Crown of Thoroughbred Racing|English Triple Crown Races]]: *# [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Lambert Simnel (horse)|Lambert Simnel]] *# [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Owen Tudor (horse)|Owen Tudor]] *# [[St. Leger Stakes]] – [[Sun Castle]] * [[Triple Crown of Thoroughbred Racing|United States Triple Crown Races]]: *# [[1941 Kentucky Derby|Kentucky Derby]] – [[Whirlaway]] *# [[Preakness Stakes]] – [[Whirlaway]] *# [[Belmont Stakes]] – [[Whirlaway]]
==[[Ice hockey]]== * [[1941 Stanley Cup Finals|Stanley Cup]] – [[1940–41 Boston Bruins season|Boston Bruins]] defeat the [[1940–41 Detroit Red Wings season|Detroit Red Wings]] 4 games to 0.
==[[Motorsport]]== {{main|1941 in motorsport|List of 1941 motorsport champions}}
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * [[The Boat Race|Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]] is not contested due to World War II
==[[Rugby league]]== *[[1941 New Zealand rugby league season]] *[[1941 NSWRFL season]] *[[1940–41 Northern Rugby Football League Wartime Emergency League season]] / [[1941–42 Northern Rugby Football League Wartime Emergency League season]]
==[[Rugby union]]== * [[Six Nations Championship|Five Nations Championship]] series is not contested due to World War II
==[[Speed skating]]== '''Speed Skating World Championships''' * not contested due to [[World War II]]
==[[Tennis]]== '''Australia''' * [[List of Australian Open Men's Singles champions|Australian Men's Singles Championship]] – ''not contested'' * [[List of Australian Open Women's Singles champions|Australian Women's Singles Championship]] – ''not contested'' '''England''' * [[List of Wimbledon Gentlemen's Singles champions|Wimbledon Men's Singles Championship]] – ''not contested'' * [[List of Wimbledon Ladies' Singles champions|Wimbledon Women's Singles Championship]] – ''not contested'' '''France''' * [[List of French Open Men's Singles champions and finalists|French Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Bernard Destremau]] (France) defeats [[Henri Cochet]] (France) 8–6, 6–2 * [[List of French Open Women's Singles champions|French Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Alice Weiwers]] (Luxembourg) † ''details to be ascertained'' '''USA''' * [[List of US Open Men's Singles champions|American Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Bobby Riggs]] (USA) defeats [[Frank Kovacs]] (USA) 5–7, 6–1, 6–3, 6–3 * [[List of US Open Women's Singles champions|American Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Sarah Palfrey Cooke]] (USA) defeats [[Pauline Betz Addie]] (USA) 7–5, 6–2 '''Davis Cup''' * 1941 International Lawn Tennis Challenge – ''not contested''
==Awards== * [[Associated Press Athlete of the Year#List of award winners|Associated Press Male Athlete of the Year]] – [[Joe DiMaggio]], [[Major League Baseball]] * [[Associated Press Athlete of the Year#List of award winners|Associated Press Female Athlete of the Year]] – [[Betty Hicks Newell]], [[golf]]
==References== {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox U.S. legislation | shorttitle = Amateur Sports Act of 1978 | othershorttitles = | longtitle = An Act to promote and coordinate amateur athletic activity in the United States, to recognize certain rights for United States amateur athletes, to provide for the resolution of disputes involving national governing bodies, and for other purposes. | colloquialacronym = | nickname = Ted Stevens Olympic and Amateur Sports Act | enacted by = 95th | effective date = November 8, 1978 | public law url = https://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/STATUTE-92/pdf/STATUTE-92-Pg3045.pdf | cite public law = 95-606 | cite statutes at large = {{usstat|92|3045}} | acts amended = | acts repealed = | title amended = [[Title 36 of the United States Code|36 U.S.C.: Patriotic Societies and Observances]] | sections created = <!--{{USC}} can be used--> | sections amended = {{unbulleted list|{{Usc-title-chap|36|2205}} § 371|{{Usc-title-chap|36|2205}} §§ 372-382b|{{Usc-title-chap|36|2205}} §§ 391-396}} | leghisturl = http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d095:SN02727:@@@R | introducedin = Senate | introducedbill = {{USBill|95|S.|2727}} | introducedby = [[Ted Stevens]] ([[Republican Party (United States)|R]]–[[Alaska|AK]]) | introduceddate = March 10, 1978 | committees = [[United States Senate Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation|Senate Commerce, Science, and Transportation]], [[United States House Committee on the Judiciary|House Judiciary]] | passedbody1 = Senate | passeddate1 = May 8, 1978 | passedvote1 = Passed | passedbody2 = House | passedas2 = <!-- used if the second body changes the name of the legislation --> | passeddate2 = October 13, 1978 | passedvote2 = Passed | conferencedate = | passedbody3 = | passeddate3 = | passedvote3 = | agreedbody3 = Senate | agreeddate3 = October 14. 1978 | agreedvote3 = Passed | agreedbody4 = <!-- used if agreedbody3 further amends legislation --> | agreeddate4 = <!-- used if agreedbody3 further amends legislation --> | agreedvote4 = <!-- used if agreedbody3 further amends legislation --> | passedbody4 = | passeddate4 = | passedvote4 = | signedpresident = Jimmy E. Carter | signeddate = November 8, 1978 | unsignedpresident = <!-- used when passed without presidential signing --> | unsigneddate = <!-- used when passed without presidential signing --> | vetoedpresident = <!-- used when passed by overriding presidential veto --> | vetoeddate = <!-- used when passed by overriding presidential veto --> | overriddenbody1 = <!-- used when passed by overriding presidential veto --> | overriddendate1 = <!-- used when passed by overriding presidential veto --> | overriddenvote1 = <!-- used when passed by overriding presidential veto --> | overriddenbody2 = <!-- used when passed by overriding presidential veto --> | overriddendate2 = <!-- used when passed by overriding presidential veto --> | overriddenvote2 = <!-- used when passed by overriding presidential veto --> | amendments = | SCOTUS cases = }} The '''Amateur Sports Act of 1978''', signed by President [[Jimmy Carter]], established the [[United States Olympic Committee]] and provides for national governing bodies for each [[Olympic sports|Olympic sport]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/ws/?pid=30133 |title= Jimmy Carter: "Amateur Sports Act of 1978 Statement on Signing S. 2727 Into Law. ," November 8, 1978 |author1=Peters, Gerhard |author2=Woolley, John T |publisher = University of California - Santa Barbara |work= The American Presidency Project}}</ref> The Act provides important legal protection for individual athletes.<ref>36 [[United States Code|U.S.C.]] § 220501</ref>
==Background== Prior to the adoption of the Act in 1978, the [[Amateur Athletic Union]] (AAU) represented the United States on international competition matters and regulated amateur sports generally. The AAU had adopted arbitrary rules which prohibited women from participating in running events and prohibited any runner who had raced in the same event as a runner with a shoe-company sponsorship. Congress adopted the Act in response to criticisms of the AAU, effectively removing that organization from any governance role.
The AAU now continues as a voluntary organization largely promoting youth sports. While it still has a major role in promoting track, it is now best known for sponsoring youth basketball competitions.
==Overview== The Act charters the U.S. Olympic Committee, which in turn can charter a national governing body (NGB) for each sport, such as [[USA Swimming]], the [[United States Fencing Association]], the [[United States Ski Team]], [[USA Track & Field]], [[USA Shooting]], or the [[U.S. Figure Skating]]. Each NGB in turn establishes the rules for selecting the United States Olympic Team and promotes amateur competition in that sport.
The Act requires that active athletes (defined as amateur athletes who have represented the United States in international amateur competition within the last ten years) must hold 20 percent of the voting power of any board or committee in an NGB. The Act also provides athletes with due process and appeal rights concerning eligibility disputes.
The Act gives exclusive rights of usage of the words ''Olympic'' and ''[[Olympiad]]'' to the Olympic Committee.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/36/220506-|title=36 U.S. Code § 220506 - Exclusive right to name, seals, emblems, and badges|website=LII / Legal Information Institute|accessdate=17 August 2018}}</ref> The Committee used this act to sue other organizations which used this term "Olympics", such as the [[Gay Olympics]].<ref name="mpbn.net">{{Cite web |url=http://www.mpbn.net/Home/tabid/36/ctl/ViewItem/mid/3478/ItemId/17541/Default.aspx |title=Archived copy |access-date=2011-11-29 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110927082357/http://www.mpbn.net/Home/tabid/36/ctl/ViewItem/mid/3478/ItemId/17541/Default.aspx |archive-date=2011-09-27 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
== 1998 Revision == The '''Ted Stevens Olympic and Amateur Sports Act''' is a [[United States]] law (codified at 36 U.S.C. Sec. 220501 et seq. of the [[United States Code]]) that charters and grants monopoly status to the [[United States Olympic Committee]], and specifies requirements for its member national [[sport governing body|governing bodies]] for individual [[sport]]s.
The current version of the Act was sponsored by [[Ted Stevens]], then–[[United States Senator|Senator]] from [[Alaska]], and adopted in 1998. It is a revision of the previous Amateur Sports Act of 1978 that reflects changes such as the fact that [[amateurism]] is no longer a requirement for competing in most international sports, expansion of the USOC's role to include the [[Paralympic Games]], increased athlete representation, and protection of the USOC against lawsuits involving athletes' right to participate in the [[Olympic Games]].
The United States Olympic Committee has used the law to force the "Gay Olympics" to change their name to the [[Gay Games]].<ref name="mpbn.net"/> The organization has threatened to use the law against the "Redneck Olympics," though it has given special dispensation to the [[Special Olympics]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sunjournal.com/oxford-hills/story/1071387|title=Redneck Olympics faces lawsuit over name - Lewiston Sun Journal|date=9 August 2011|publisher=|accessdate=17 August 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sunjournal.com/oxford-hills/story/1071616|title=Redneck Olympics faces lawsuit over name - Lewiston Sun Journal|date=9 August 2011|publisher=|accessdate=17 August 2018}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
==External links== * [https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/36/220501- Text of Act] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20050525010736/http://www.olympic.org/uk/index_uk.asp International Olympic Committee Website] * [http://www.usoc.org US Olympic Committee Website] * [http://www.soccerpark.com/TedStevens.pdf Text of the Ted Stevens Olympic and Amateur Sports Act]
[[Category:1978 in law]] [[Category:95th United States Congress]] [[Category:History of sports in the United States]] [[Category:1977 in American sports]] [[Category:1998 in American sports]] [[Category:Amateur Athletic Union]] [[Category:United States federal legislation]] [[Category:United States at the Olympics]] [[Category:1978 in American law]] [[Category:Sports law]]

revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/Michaelbrown12345|Michaelbrown12345]] ([[User talk:Michaelbrown12345|talk]]): Unsourced trivia. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{Use American English|date=October 2017}} [[File:Gorra MLB.JPG|thumb|upright=1.2|A typical baseball cap; this one is an [[Oakland Athletics]] cap.]] A '''baseball cap''' is a type of soft [[cap]] with a rounded crown and a stiff peak projecting in front.
The front of the cap typically contains a design or a [[logo]] of sports team (namely a [[baseball]] team, or names of relevant companies, when used as a commercial marketing technique). The back of the cap may be "fitted" to the wearer's head size or it may have a [[plastic]], [[Hook and loop fastener|Velcro]], or [[Stretch fabric|elastic]] and [[zipper strip]], adjuster so that it can be quickly adjusted to fit different wearers. The baseball cap is a part of the traditional [[baseball uniform]] worn by players, with the brim pointing forward to shield the eyes from the sun. Since the 1980s varieties of the cap have become a common fashion accessory, particularly in the [[United States]].
== History == [[File:Jackie Robinson, Brooklyn Dodgers, 1954.jpg|alt=Jackie Robinson Wearing A Brooklyn Dodgers Baseball Cap|thumb|upright|[[Jackie Robinson]] wearing a baseball cap]] [[File:1888 Reds.jpg|thumb|right|Portrait of [[Cincinnati Reds]] players, 1888]]
In 1860, the [[Brooklyn Excelsiors]] wore the ancestor of the modern rounded-top baseball cap, which featured a long peak and a button on top, and by 1900, the "Brooklyn style" cap became popular.<ref name="usatoday">{{cite web|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/sports/baseball/2006-07-25-cap_x.htm|title=Baseball cap has endured generations as the all-American hat|accessdate=2014-04-26}}</ref> During the 1940s, latex rubber became the stiffening material inside the hat and the modern baseball cap was born. The peak, also known in certain areas as the "bill" or "brim", was designed to protect a player's eyes from the sun. Typically, the peak was much shorter in the earlier days of the baseball hat. Also, the hat has become more structured, versus the overall "floppy" cap of the 19th and early 20th centuries. The baseball cap was and still is an important means by which to identify a team. Often the logo, [[mascot]], or team's initial was placed on the cap. Usually, the cap was also fashioned in the official colors of a particular team.
The basic shape, including curved peak, is similar to some styles of 19th century sun bonnets.<ref name=bonnet>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/magazine/3660333.stm BBC – Happy 59th, baseball caps] 18 December 2008</ref>
== Design == Fitted baseball caps — those without an adjuster — are normally sewn in six sections, and may be topped with a matching fabric-covered [[button (clothing)|button]] (also called a squatchee) on the crown. Metal grommets or fabric eyelets are often sewn or attached near the top of each of the six sections of fabric to provide ventilation. In some cases, the rear sections of the crown are made of net-like mesh material for extra ventilation. The peak is typically stiffened by a sewn-in piece of [[paperboard]] or stiff plastic.
=== Variations === Baseball caps are made of many types of material and shaped in various styles for different purposes. Major and minor league baseball players wear classic-style caps made of [[wool]] (or, more recently, [[polyester]]) with their team's simple logo and colors; the logo is usually [[Embroidery|embroidered]] into the fabric. More recently there are brands that are using uncommon materials for snapback hats as for example wood brims.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.capcollectors.com/feature/want-wooden-brim-strapback-weve-got-covered/|title=Want a wooden brim strapback? We've got you covered|last=Dabrowiecki|first=Jamie|date=2016-11-07|accessdate=2018-02-04}}</ref>
Formerly, baseball caps only came in standard hat sizes. Since the early 70's, they have also been available in a one-size-fits-all form, with an adjustment strap in the back. The style, commonly called snapback, has become increasingly popular as fashion accessories.<ref name="mensfashion">{{cite web|url=http://www.mensfashionmagazine.com/mens-fashion-trend-snapback-caps|title=Mens Fashion Trend: Snapback Caps|accessdate=2014-04-26}}</ref> Advances in textiles have led to the "stretch-fit" hat, which uses Lycra or rubber to allow a hat to have a fitted style while still being "adjustable" within sizes.
[[File:Truckerhat.jpg|thumb|Trucker cap]] The front may be soft, or may be stiffened by [[buckram]] to display a logo more clearly.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://threadlogic.wordpress.com/2012/12/20/whats-the-difference-between-a-constructed-and-an-unconstructed-cap/|title=What's the difference between a constructed and an unconstructed cap?|last=Taxdahl|first=Jeff|date=2012-12-20|access-date=2017-01-06}}</ref>
Another version of the baseball cap is a plastic mesh cap with a foam front imprinted with a company logo. This style is sometimes called a [[Trucker hat|trucker cap]] or a "gimme cap" because it is given away for free as a promotional item.
Dad hats are unstructured caps with low profile, curved brim, and stripe on the back.
There are 3 major types of baseball caps: # Snapback hat - (hat with a snap closure in the rear) with flat brim, high profile, adjustable. # Adjustable hat - unstructured, low profile, curved brim, adjustable. # Fitted hat - curved or flat brim, structured cap, high profile, not adjustable.
== Athletic use == [[File:Paul Hoover.jpg|thumb|right|In baseball, caps are worn backwards to accommodate for a [[Catcher#Equipment|face mask]] by some catchers and are worn under the mask of umpires.]]
Beginning with the 2014 season, [[MLB]] pitchers are permitted to wear a special reinforced cap to protect their heads from line drives.<ref name="dailynews">{{cite web|url=http://m.nydailynews.com/1.1594040|title=MLB approves protective cap for pitchers in time for 2014 season|accessdate=2014-04-26}}</ref>
Athletes in other sports wear caps with their team's logo and colors as "sideline" caps; both types are also sold as authentic team merchandise in retail stores. Other caps may simply have a maker's logo, such as [[Reebok]], [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]] or [[Carhartt]]; these hats are often made of brushed [[cotton]]. Golfers tend to prefer the [[sports visor]] form which does not cover the head but keeps the sun out of their eyes; women also traditionally have worn visors casually but a trend in certain youth subcultures sees an increase in feminine use of full caps.
== Professional use ==
=== Military === [[File:US Navy 040527-N-4104L-001 Guided missile destroyer USS Russell (DDG 59), Commanding Officer, Cmdr. William Kearns III, communicates with his combat information center.jpg|thumb|left|Baseball caps worn by naval officers from the US, Singapore, Thailand, Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, and the Philippines.]] Some armed forces use baseball caps as part of their uniforms, including the [[United States Navy]] and [[United States Coast Guard]]. Used mostly with the utility uniform and coveralls, the baseball cap usually has a command logo on the front to denote command affiliation. Baseball caps of a particular color are worn to denote a specific function of a person or particular job. For example, in the [[United States]] [[submarine]] force, red baseball caps are worn by drill monitors who facilitate and critique members of the boat's crew during drills. In the [[United States Army]], [[parachute rigger]]s wear red baseball caps and parachute instructors wear black baseball caps as part of their uniform. In various squadrons of the [[United States Air Force]]'s [[Civil Air Patrol|civilian auxiliary]], squadron-distinctive baseball caps have been issued as headgear (or "cover") for the [[Battle Dress Uniform]], typically displaying squadron colors, squadron number, and/or squadron patch. Although the BDUs have their own cover, a [[patrol cap]] in [[M81 Woodland]], some squadrons have opted for more distinctive covers.
=== Police === [[File:Poliiseja ja rajavartijoita partioveneellä.jpg|thumb|right|[[Police of Finland|Finnish police]] wearing baseball caps, with [[Finnish Border Guard]] agents wearing side caps.]] In many United States police forces, the baseball cap is worn as a more practical alternative to the traditional [[peaked cap]] or [[campaign hat]], the latter of which is generally used by [[Sheriffs in the United States|Sheriff's]] departments and [[State police (United States)|state police]] forces. This is more common on the [[West Coast of the United States|West Coast]], whereas in eastern states the traditional peaked cap is more prominent. A notable exception is the [[San Francisco Police Department]], where peaked caps are still worn regularly. In [[Slovenia]], policemen on motorcycles wear baseball caps as a part of their uniform, when they remove the helmet. The baseball cap is also commonly used by private security companies as a cheap, practical piece of uniform headgear.
There has been a marked trend in recent years among police forces and other uniformed bodies throughout the world to substitute cheap and comfortable baseball caps for peaked caps and other traditional headdresses. In Britain the baseball cap has the additional advantage of being unisex and suitable for wear by both male and female officers. During 2017 the Northamptonshire, Cheshire and Lancashire police forces adopted specially strengthened baseball caps known as "Bump Caps", to replace the helmets and bowler hats previously worn.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/05/10/police-swap-helmets-caps-attract-transgender-officers/|title=Police swap helmets for caps to attract more transgender officers|first=Nicola|last=Harley|date=10 May 2017|publisher=|via=www.telegraph.co.uk}}</ref> The [[Police of Finland|Finnish Police]] uses a baseball cap ([http://www.poliisi.fi/finnish_police/police_uniforms ''seen on the image at this link'']), which is considered an official identification device and cannot be worn or even displayed by civilians, and has mostly replaced the traditional [[side cap]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.lansi-uusimaa.fi/artikkeli/8594-poliisilippista-on-laitonta-pitaa-esilla|title=Poliisilippistä on laitonta pitää esillä|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://yle.fi/uutiset/3-5894937|title=Lakki on poliisille tärkeä turvallisuusvaruste|website=Yle Uutiset}}</ref> Many armed police units around the world, notably [[SWAT]] in the United States and [[Metropolitan Police]]'s [[Specialist Firearms Command]] in the [[United Kingdom]], often wear baseball caps to shield their eyes from the sun where a full helmet would be excessive.
== See also == {{Portal|Baseball|Fashion}} * [[Baseball clothing and equipment]] * [[Beanie (seamed cap)]] * [[Cricket cap]], a similar cap in a similar sport * [[Flat cap]] * [[List of headgear]]

[[Category:American fashion]] [[Category:Baseball equipment]] [[Category:Canadian fashion]] [[Category:Caps]] [[Category:Fashion accessories]] [[Category:Headgear]] [[Category:Hip hop fashion]] [[Category:History of clothing (Western fashion)]] [[Category:Sports clothing]]

A '''Beer League''' (North American English) is a recreational league for adults to drink beer and compete in different sports. While the '''pub league''' (British English) is a form of [[sports league]] actually primarily funded by sponsorships from [[pub]]s, [[tavern]]s and [[bar (establishment)|bars]]. The bars often provide funding for a team's uniforms and equipment, and often a free drink for each player, in exchange for advertising the establishment on the uniform and usually [[naming rights]] to the team itself. Beer leagues can be of virtually any sport but are usually [[amateur sports|amateur]] and recreational in nature, not being tied to a larger competitive [[league system]], and contested by adults. The consumption of alcohol is often encouraged during the contest, as the actual competition is secondary. This is beneficial to the adults that compete in these beer league events because not only are they supporting a small business, but they are getting physical activity, all while being social. For example, with Beer League Hockey over 174,000 adults play. The special thing behind these leagues is that "It’s organized hockey in its purest form, unencumbered by money, skill, ambition, fans or advancement." <ref>Bonander, Ross. “Inside the World of Beer League Hockey.” DRAFT, 14 Dec. 2015, https://draftmag.com/beer-league-hockey/</ref>
[[Category: Sports leagues]]
