page.title: Personal finances of professional American athletes

revision.comment: /* Players' vulnerabilities */ Removed a dead citation.
revision.text:
The '''personal finances of professional American athletes''' is a subject of widespread discussion due to the often high salaries of such athletes and the high rates of [[personal bankruptcy]] and other financial distress.
According to a 2009 ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'' article, 78% of [[National Football League]] (NFL) players are either [[Bankruptcy|bankrupt]] or are under financial stress within two years of retirement and an estimated 60% of [[National Basketball Association]] (NBA) players go bankrupt within five years after leaving their sport.<ref name=SI>{{cite news |url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1153364/1/index.htm |title=How (and Why) Athletes Go Broke |author=Pablo S. Torre |publisher=''[[Sports Illustrated]]'' |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090811090257/http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1153364/1/index.htm | archivedate=2009-08-11 | date=March 23, 2009 |accessdate=January 6, 2011}}</ref> Originally the statement "60% of NBA players go bankrupt within five years after leaving their sport" was released by a representative of the [[NBA Players' Association]] in 2008 <ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.thestar.com/sports/basketball/2008/01/31/nba_players_financial_security_no_slam_dunk.html | location=Toronto | work=The Star}}</ref><ref>http://www.pearlswindow.com/2008/02/do-60-of-nba-players-go-broke-5-years.html</ref> A ''[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]'' magazine article states, however, that a working paper from the [[National Bureau of Economic Research]] found that the percentage of NFL players who go bankrupt after two years is a much smaller 1.9%, climbing to 15.7% after 12 years.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Roberts |first1=Daniel |date=April 15, 2015 |title=16% of retired NFL players go bankrupt, a report says |journal=Fortune |url=http://fortune.com/2015/04/15/nfl-players-bankrupt/}}</ref>
==History== {{asof|1911}} the average salary for the about 500 players in [[Major League Baseball]] was slightly more than $2,000 a season (${{Inflation|US|2,000|1911|fmt=c|r=-2}} today). The star hitter [[Ty Cobb]] received $9,000 a season (${{Inflation|US|9,000|1911|fmt=c|r=-2}} today), and sold automobiles in the off season. While Cobb encouraged young men to play professionally, top pitcher [[Christy Mathewson]]—who had made more money as a player than Cobb—warned, "Keep out of baseball unless you are sure of being a star!" He stated that the average player did not make enough over a ten-year career to justify devoting those years to the sport.<ref name="fox191105">{{cite news | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VcLQAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA147&hl=en&sa=X&ei=DIPgUqTJG4bpoAT1u4LAAQ&ved=0CDoQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&f=false | title=Baseball as the Players See It | work=Outing Magazine |date=May 1911| accessdate=22 January 2014 | author=Fox, Edward Lyell | pages=143}}</ref>
By 1941, [[Hank Greenberg]] was the highest-paid player in baseball, earning $55,000 a season (${{Inflation|US|55,000|1941|fmt=c|r=-2}} today).<ref name="life19410519">{{cite news | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6U4EAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PA45&pg=PA45#v=onepage&f=true | title=Army Inducts Highest-paid Baseball Player | work=Life | date=1941-05-19 | accessdate=22 January 2014 | pages=45}}</ref> [[Stan Musial]]'s $80,000 a season (${{Inflation|US|80,000|1952|fmt=c|r=-2}} today) was the highest in 1952, while young star [[Mickey Mantle]] earned $10,000 a season (${{Inflation|US|10,000|1952|fmt=c|r=-2}} today). Musial, like Cobb, supplemented his income; he owned a restaurant.<ref name="life19520915">{{cite news | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cVYEAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PA71&dq=baseball%20salary&pg=PA71#v=onepage&q=baseball%20salary&f=false | title=An Old Pro and a Young One | work=Life | date=1952-09-15 | accessdate=22 January 2014 | pages=71}}</ref>
==Players' vulnerabilities== Baseball outfielder [[Torii Hunter]] brought up another obstacle: "Once you get into the financial stuff, and it sounds like Japanese, guys are just like, 'I ain't going back.' They're lost."<ref name=SI/> It has been often suggested that baseball players study finance in college so that they can understand basic finances and contracts.
Players encourage each other to spend lavishly. [[Rod Strickland]] explained, "For rookies, it's like an unspoken initiation ... You're trying to get in good with the veterans, so you go beyond your means."<ref name=SI/> Friends and strangers become part of their entourages. Retired basketball center [[Danny Schayes]] stated, "Guys go broke because they surround themselves with people who help them go broke".<ref name=ESPN>{{cite web |url=http://sports.espn.go.com/espnmag/story?id=3469271 |title=Life of Reilly |author=Rick Reilly |publisher=[[ESPN]] |accessdate=January 6, 2011}}</ref>
An additional problem is that players can earn money in many different tax jurisdictions, and be a citizen of one country but a legal resident of another.<ref>{{cite web | url =http://www.marketwatch.com/story/why-so-many-pro-athletes-run-into-tax-troubles-2016-02-05 | title =Why so many sports stars run into tax troubles | last =Bischoff | first =Bill | date =6 February 2016 | website =Market Watch | publisher = | access-date =7 February 2016 | quote =Due to complicated tax issues that don’t affect the rest of us, even financially literate athletes can wind up in tax trouble if they have less-than-stellar advisers. }}</ref>
==Length of careers== "There's a far shorter peak earnings period than in any other profession".<ref name=SI/> ''[[Black Enterprise]]'' reported in 2003 that "the average career span for professional basketball, football, and baseball is a mere 4.5 years, 3.2 years, and under five years, respectively."<ref name=BE>{{cite news |url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1365/is_8_33/ai_97910693/?tag=content;col1 |title=A brand new game: for these athletes, entrepreneurship is the next playing field - Entrepreneurship |author=Alan Hughes |publisher=''[[Black Enterprise]]'' magazine |date=March 2003 |accessdate=January 6, 2011}}</ref> A 2007 study found that, excluding pitchers, rookie Major League Baseball players' careers last for 5.6 years on average.<ref name="roberts20070715">{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/07/15/sports/baseball/15careers.html | title=Just How Long Does the Average Baseball Career Last? | work=The New York Times | date=2007-07-15 | accessdate=14 April 2015 | author=Roberts, Sam}}</ref>
==Managers and investments== [[Magic Johnson]] said, "They hire these people not because of expertise but because they're friends. Well, they'll fail."<ref name=SI/> [[Rod Strickland]] made his father his business manager. The older Strickland checked out a real estate deal from a "friend of a close friend" of Rod's, but not well enough to avoid a costly blunder.<ref name=SI/>
Hockey Hall of Famer [[Bobby Orr]] received deceitful treatment from [[Alan Eagleson]], who "as Orr's agent, left him all but broke as part of one of sports' most spectacular financial scandals."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1152491/index.htm |title=The Ever Elusive, Always Inscrutable And Still Incomparable Bobby Orr |author=S. L. Price |publisher=''Sports Illustrated'' |date=March 2, 2009 |accessdate=January 7, 2011}}</ref>
[[Karl Malone]], another Basketball Hall of Famer has said, "You get in trouble when you let a lot of people close to you . . . I've made my share of mistakes. You've got to learn from them.<ref name=Malone>{{cite news|url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/765586197/From-the-Mailman-to-a-businessman-Karl-Malone-still-delivers-the-goods.html?pg=all |title=From the Mailman to a businessman, Karl Malone still delivers the goods |first=Doug |last=Robinson |newspaper=[[Deseret News]] |date=June 26, 2012 |accessdate=July 25, 2012}}</ref>
==Spouses, children and divorce== When asked by one of his players "What's the most dangerous thing that could happen to us financially?", [[Carolina Panthers]] majority owner [[Jerry Richardson]] replied immediately, "Divorce."<ref name=SI/> The money stops flowing in. Without a [[prenuptial agreement]],<ref name=SI/> [[Michael Jordan]]'s $168 million divorce settlement was at the time the largest ever.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,266343,00.html |title=Forbes: Michael Jordan's Divorce Most Costly Ever |publisher=Fox News |date=April 16, 2007 |accessdate=January 7, 2011}}</ref> On the other hand, [[Dikembe Mutombo]] canceled his wedding, when his fiancee refused to sign one the day before the ceremony.<ref name=SI/>
Another factor is the sexual opportunities available to athletes during their careers. Players end up being responsible for [[child support]]. [[Shawn Kemp]] had at least seven children with six women,<ref name=SI/> [[Derrick Thomas]] seven with five,<ref name=SI/> [[Jon Kilgore]] fifteen with four, and [[Travis Henry]] nine with nine.<ref>{{cite news |title=With Nine Mouths to Feed, Travis Henry Says He’s Broke |author=Mike Tierney |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |date=March 11, 2009 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/12/sports/football/12henry.html}}</ref> Henry was imprisoned for non-payment of an estimated $170,000 annually.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/10-ways-sports-stars-destroy-their-finances-2009-9#have-too-many-children-6 |title=10 Ways Sports Stars Go From Riches To Rags |author=Lawrence Delevingne |publisher=[[Business Insider]] |date=September 12, 2009 |accessdate=January 7, 2011}}</ref>
==Education==
The [[National Football League]] offers its players a Financial Education Program. "The non-credit seminars are offered during the year and teach players about cash management, insurance, tax planning, retirement planning and other related topics."<ref name=NFL>{{cite web |url=http://www.nfl.com/playerdevelopment/finance |title=Financial Education |publisher=nfl.com |accessdate=January 6, 2011}}</ref> There is also a more advanced NFL Business Management and Entrepreneurial Program, with "custom programs at top-rated business schools".<ref name=NFL/>
[[Ryerson University]]'s [[Ted Rogers School of Management]] offers a program called Breakaway, which aims to help players in their transition away from professional hockey and other sports.<ref>{{cite news |title=Education for when a hockey career gets put on ice |author=Danielle Webb |newspaper=[[The Globe and Mail]] |date=January 5, 2011 |url=http://m.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/managing/business-education/education-for-when-a-hockey-career-gets-put-on-ice/article1857046/?service=mobile}}</ref>
Education can often be overlooked by professional athletes, once they have made it to their desired sports league. This is a major concern because many professional athletes have no funds or career options to fall back on.<ref name="Caryna">{{cite web|last=Caryna|first=John|title=Why a college degree is important for professional athletes|publisher=Helium|accessdate=8 April 2012}}</ref> Without a college degree, higher education, or in some instances even a high school diploma; there are limited options to explore in the world outside of athletics.<ref name="Caryna"/> Well established athletes like Shaquille O'Neal and Ray Lewis have gone back to receive their college degrees, despite their incredible success in their respected athletic professions.<ref name="Caryna"/> One side of the argument says that college athletics and the educational institutions often do not succeed in accommodating their student athletes for their future endeavors outside of sports, and that the overall relationship between schools and athletes can be perceived as commercial, rather than educational.<ref name="McCormick">{{cite web|last=McCormick|first=A. C|title=The myth of the student-athlete: The college athlete as employee|url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/213127627?accountid=11091|publisher=Washington Law Review|accessdate=8 April 2012}}</ref>
In college athletics, such as basketball and football, coaches appear to control athletes in and out of season of their respected sport.<ref name="McCormick"/> With incredibly demanding schedules that almost always requires players to miss classes to focus on their athletic performance, one side of the argument is that it can be difficult to state that schools implement policies and coaches that respect athletics and education equally at a university.<ref name="McCormick"/> Universities have been able to counter these arguments by complying with NCAA rules on limits of practice time and extracurricular activities for the sport that do not pertain to the classroom.<ref name="Caudill">{{cite web|last=Caudill|first=Steven|title=The Impact of Participation in Intercollegiate Athletics on Income and Graduation|jstor=2109580|publisher=The MIT Press|accessdate=8 April 2012}}</ref> Universities often argue that not only do these athletes receive an opportunity of a higher education that they might not have necessarily been able to receive, but that these skills enhance competitive drive, discipline, and teamwork skills in future work settings.<ref name="Caudill"/> Scholarships often provide opportunities for those who may not have gotten into a university, based on previous academic performance or financial status, have been the one of the central arguments for universities justifying their athletic standing and policies.<ref name="Caudill"/> Additional arguments now cite the importance of the synergies in the valuable knowledge and experience gained on the field and how these skills are applied in the workplace.<ref name="Caudill"/> In a study done about the mean attribution of life skills to the sport experience, 75% of former athletes who were participants stated that there were major life skills associated with sports that transferred to their working lives.<ref name="Barton">{{cite web|last=Barton|first=Gavin|title=Career success and life skill development through sports|url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/880398589?accountid=11091|publisher=Boston University|accessdate=8 April 2012}}</ref> This study analyzed different types of experiential learning, and found that these were often experiential skills that were learned through playing sports that included what ranged from leadership to goal setting.<ref name="Barton"/> These arguments may more commonly come up to defend universities for implementing high standards in athletic performance.<ref name="Caudill"/> Regardless of these allegations against universities, education is extremely valuable to professional athletes because the average athlete rarely has a long tenure and cannot make their income last for a sustained period of time.<ref name="Caryna"/>
Some believe that the universities are not to blame, and that students often pave their own path. In a survey consisting of previous student athletes, athletic performance and effort was attributed to helping the development of major life skills, especially in the work force.<ref name="Barton"/> However, this can change from person to person, and social theorists even believe that roles and identities contribute heavily to where a person is headed in life.<ref name="Preacco">{{cite web|last=Preacco|first=Lara|title=Student-athlete worldview: A qualitative discovery of student-athletes outlook of the world through their athletic experiences|url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/305037662?accountid=|publisher=Western Michigan University|accessdate=8 April 2012}}</ref> There are some athletes, whose personality caters to working incredibly hard on the field, rather than off the field, thus developing more of an athletic identity that can get in the way of a career path or education.<ref name="Preacco"/> The same goes with those who have passions in education or some other activity, making student athletes think very differently from one another.<ref name="Preacco"/>
==Successes==
===Basketball=== [[Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame|Basketball Hall of Famer]] Magic Johnson is an example of an athlete who has not only kept his money, but increased it. He has built a thriving business empire.<ref name=SI/> He was at one time a part owner of the [[Los Angeles Lakers]], and his company, Magic Johnson Enterprises, has a net worth of $700 million. In 2012, he was a minority partner in [[Guggenheim Partners|a group]] that bought the [[Los Angeles Dodgers]].
Michael Jordan has proven almost as successful in his post-basketball business ventures, despite a temporary financial setback due to his divorce. He has numerous business interests, most notably his own line of apparel through [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]]. In March 2010, he became the majority owner of the Charlotte Bobcats, now known as the [[Charlotte Hornets]], after buying out most of the interest of founding owner [[Robert L. Johnson|Bob Johnson]] for $275 million.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nba/news/story?id=4989536 |title=Jordan soon to get reins of Bobcats |author=[[Associated Press]] |work=[[ESPN.com]] |date=March 13, 2010 |accessdate=May 13, 2011}}</ref>
Another Hall of Famer, [[Dave Bing]], established a steel processing company, Bing Steel, in [[Detroit]] in 1980. After Bing Steel suffered a loss in its first year of operation, Bing decided to shift his company from manufacturing to being a middleman. Bing Steel became profitable in its second year of operation, and has since expanded to become the Bing Group, a conglomerate involved in a number of businesses, including supplying the automotive industry. However, it has been recently announced that the Bing Group is heavily in debt and is in process of being sold. Most of his holdings have either gone bankrupt or been dissolved.
Still another Hall of Famer, [[Karl Malone]], was involved in a substantial number of business ventures during his NBA career, with his involvement both expanding and diversifying since his retirement. A 2012 story in the ''[[Deseret News]]'' of [[Salt Lake City]], where he played almost all of his NBA career, listed his current ventures. Among these are new-car and used-car dealerships in the Salt Lake City area; a cattle ranch and substantial timber property in his home state of [[Louisiana]]; restaurants in Louisiana, Utah and [[Idaho]]; a commercial development company; a deer-raising venture; and an outfitting business.<ref name=Malone/>
===Baseball=== [[National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum|Hall of Fame]] pitcher [[Nolan Ryan]] has proven successful in business, though not at the level of Johnson or Jordan. After the end of his playing career in 1993, he was majority owner and chairman of a bank in his home town of [[Alvin, Texas]] before selling his interest in 2005. He also became part owner of two [[Minor league baseball|minor-league]] teams in his home state, the [[Corpus Christi Hooks]] and [[Round Rock Express]]. In 2010, he was the public face of, and a minority investor in, a group that bought the [[Texas Rangers (baseball)|Texas Rangers]], the team with which he finished his [[Major League Baseball]] playing career. He owned a controlling interest in the team until late 2013, when he sold his stake after differences with the majority partners of the Rangers.
===Football=== Former [[Washington Redskins]] cornerback [[Eugene Profit]] parlayed his [[Yale University|Yale]] economics education into a highly successful financial career. His company, Profit Investment Management, looks after $2 billion in assets.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2011/writers/damon_hack/06/16/eugene.profit/index.html?xid=cnnbin&hpt=hp_bn10 |title=Playing for Profit: Ex-NFL corner succeeds in business after football |author=Damon Hack |publisher=''[[Sports Illustrated]]'' |date=June 16, 2011 |accessdate=June 16, 2011}}</ref> Former [[Denver Broncos]] quarterback and Pro Football Hall of Fame member [[John Elway]] used his football earnings to launch a chain of automotive dealerships and steakhouses.<ref name="empire">espn.com, [http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/wire?section=nfl&id=2744058 Elway expands business empire, opening new steakhouse]</ref>
==Mixed results== Another athlete turned successful businessman, at least for a time, was former football safety [[Dave Duerson]], president and CEO of Duerson Foods L.L.C.<ref name=BE/> However, an expansion of his company turned into financial disaster due to issues with a supplier of freezers for a meat processing plant. Duerson Foods won a $34 million judgment against the freezer company in 2004, but never collected because the company later filed for bankruptcy, and Duerson himself filed for bankruptcy in September 2010.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/chicago/nfl/news/story?id=6146920 |title=Duerson filed for bankruptcy |work=[[ESPN.com|ESPNChicago.com]] |date=February 22, 2011 |accessdate=May 13, 2011}}</ref> Duerson's story turned far more tragic, as he committed suicide in February 2011, and a post-mortem examination of his brain revealed he was suffering from what was described as a "moderately advanced" case of [[chronic traumatic encephalopathy]], presumably from constant blows to the head during his football career.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/chicago/nfl/news/story?id=6465271 |title=Dave Duerson had brain damage |work=[[ESPN.com|ESPNChicago.com]] |date=May 3, 2011 |accessdate=May 13, 2011}}</ref>
==Failures==
[[Vince Young]] – After earning $45 million in salary and endorsements, Young is one of the most recent pro athletes to go broke.
[[Antoine Walker]] – Despite earning $108 million in salary while playing in the NBA, Walker had to declare bankruptcy in 2010 listing assets of $5 million and debts of $13 million thanks to bad real estate investments and gambling debts.
[[Evander Holyfield]] – After earning $250 million as a heavyweight champion, in 2008 a bank foreclosed on Holyfield's $10 million, 54,000 square foot, 109 room Atlanta mansion.
[[Kenny Anderson (basketball)|Kenny Anderson]] – Despite earning $63 million in salary, Anderson was broke the day he left the NBA. After filing for bankruptcy, Anderson became a K-12 school teacher.
[[Warren Sapp]] – In April 2012, Sapp filed for bankruptcy claiming assets worth $6.5 million and debts of $7 million. The $7 million is owed to the IRS, [[child support]] to four different women, and medical bills.
[[Allen Iverson]] – In February 2012, Iverson told a Georgia judge that he was flat broke and could not pay an $860k jewelry debt. Iverson earned $154 million in salary and $30–50 million in endorsements during his career. Iverson was known to travel with a 50-person entourage, lost millions of dollars gambling, lavished friends with expensive gifts and had massive monthly child support obligations.
[[Mike Tyson]] - earned an estimated $400 million over his career, but declared bankruptcy in 2003.<ref name=Forbes>{{cite news |url=https://www.forbes.com/2008/11/25/unitas-borg-money-biz-sports-cx_af_1125athletefinances.html |title=Sports Stars' Money Meltdowns |author=Andrew Farrell |publisher=Forbes |date=November 25, 2008 |accessdate=January 7, 2011}}</ref>
[[Sheryl Swoopes]] earned an estimated $50 million playing basketball, and declared bankruptcy in 2004, owing $711,050.<ref name=Swoops>{{cite news |title=Swoopes Says She Is Gay, and Exhales |author=Liz Robbins |newspaper=New York Times |date=October 27, 2005 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/10/27/sports/basketball/27swoopes.html?pagewanted=all}}</ref> Swoopes admitted, "I didn't surround myself with the right people. I got in a position where it was like, 'Oh, wow, what happened?'"<ref name=Swoops/>
Former [[Boston Red Sox]] star [[Jack Clark (baseball)|Jack Clark]] filed for bankruptcy in the middle of his $8.7-million-dollar contract.{{citation needed|date=January 2013}}
==References== {{reflist|33em}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Personal Finances Of Professional American Athletes}} [[Category:Sports business]]

{{EngvarB|date=July 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2016}} In team [[sport]]s, a '''man of the match'''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://en.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/man_of_the_match|title=man of the match - definition of man of the match in English - Oxford Dictionaries|website=Oxford Dictionaries - English|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161025173131/https://en.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/man_of_the_match|archivedate=25 October 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> award is often given to the outstanding player in a particular match. This can be a player from either team, although the player is generally chosen from the winning team.
Some sports have unique traditions regarding these awards, and they are especially sought-after in championship or [[all-star game|all-star]] games. In Australia, the term "[[best and fairest]]" is normally used, both for individual games and season-long awards. In some competitions, particularly in North America, the terms "[[most valuable player]]" (MVP) or "most outstanding player" (MOP) are used. In [[ice hockey]] in North America, three players of the game, called the "[[three stars (ice hockey)|three stars]]", are recognised.
In sports where playoffs are decided by series rather than individual games, such as professional basketball and baseball, MVP awards are commonly given for the series, and in ice hockey's [[National Hockey League|NHL]], for performance in the entire playoffs.
==Association football== In football, the "man of the match" award typically goes to a player on the winning side. Players who score a [[hat-trick]], or [[Goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeepers]] who keep a [[Shutout#Association football|clean sheet]] under pressure often get the award. Hat-trick scorers usually receive the match ball whether or not they are officially named man of the match.
The man of the match is often chosen by a television commentator or a sponsor.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2008/feb/27/sport.comment4|title=Football: The problem with man of the match awards|first=Si|last=Hawkins|date=27 February 2008|website=the Guardian|accessdate=6 May ghg2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180301170032/https://www.theguardian.com/football/2008/feb/27/sport.comment4|archivedate=1 March 2018|df=dmy-all}}</ref> However, not all competitions have an official man of the match award, so sometimes accolades are given by websites or newspapers instead. In the [[Premier League]], for example, a player receives a small black and gold trophy for their man of the match performance.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.premierleague.com/news/83956|title=How the Premier League's monthly awards work|publisher=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170204082122/https://www.premierleague.com/news/83956|archivedate=4 February 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-3742900/Premier-League-s-new-man-match-award-yellow-brick-poking-fun-new-design.html|title=Premier League's new man-of-the-match award is a gold coloured brick|author=|date=|website=dailymail.co.uk|accessdate=6 May 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161019220257/http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-3742900/Premier-League-s-new-man-match-award-yellow-brick-poking-fun-new-design.html|archivedate=19 October 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
[[File:Soccer-1490541 960 720.jpg|thumb|Men playing football, also known as soccer.]]
==Australian rules football== In [[Australian rules football]], the player of the game is often referred to as having been the "best on ground" (or "BOG"). Media outlets provide immediate, unofficial recognition that is largely honorary, often on a 5–4–3–2–1 or 3–2–1 voting basis.{{cn|date=March 2018}} Players may receive a [[Tissot]] watch as an award for their "best on ground" performance.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.richmondfc.com.au/video/2016-08-06/round-20-rance-wins-the-tissot|title=Round 20: Rance wins the Tissot - richmondfc.com.au|publisher=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161019220230/http://www.richmondfc.com.au/video/2016-08-06/round-20-rance-wins-the-tissot|archivedate=19 October 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Officially, the [[Australian Football League|AFL]] recognises the player of the game as being the player awarded the maximum three votes by umpires in the [[Brownlow Medal]] count at season's end. Exceptions are made during the season for certain reserved games such as the [[Western Derby]], [[The ANZAC Day clash]], [[QClash]], and [[Showdown (AFL)|Showdown]], where medallions are officially rewarded in presentations following the conclusion of the match. On the day of the [[AFL Grand Final]], a player will be awarded the [[Norm Smith Medal]] as being the best on ground voted by an independent panel of [[Australian rules football]] experts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.afl.com.au/stats/awards/norm-smith-medal|title=Norm Smith Medal - AFL.com.au|website=afl.com.au|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161016135158/http://www.afl.com.au/stats/awards/norm-smith-medal|archivedate=16 October 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Cricket== {{main article|Player of the Match awards (cricket)}} In cricket, the man of the match award became a regular feature in Test matches in the mid 1980s.<ref name="test motm">{{cite web |url=http://stats.espncricinfo.com/ci/content/records/283704.html |title=Records / Test matches / Individual records (captains, players, umpires) /Most player-of-the-match awards |work=ESPN Cricinfo |publisher=ESPN Sports Media |accessdate=2 January 2014 |date= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140303223723/http://stats.espncricinfo.com/ci/content/records/283704.html |archivedate=3 March 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The man of the match title is usually awarded to the player whose contribution is seen as the most critical in winning the game.
In one match held on 3 April 1996, the whole team from [[New Zealand national cricket team|New Zealand]] was awarded the Men of the Match award. It was the first instance when a whole team was awarded it.<ref>{{cite web|title=4th ODI: West Indies v New Zealand at Georgetown, Apr 3, 1996 | Cricket Scorecard | ESPN Cricinfo|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/engine/match/64524.html|website=ESPN Cricinfo|publisher=ESPN|accessdate=24 March 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150404011441/http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/engine/match/64524.html|archivedate=4 April 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In a test match played between 15,16,17,18 January 1999 between South Africa vs West Indies, the whole South African team was awarded man of the match <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/engine/match/63823.html|title=5th Test, West Indies tour of South Africa at Centurion, Jan 15-18 1999 - Match Summary - ESPNCricinfo|website=ESPNcricinfo|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121106053428/http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/engine/match/63823.html|archivedate=6 November 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In Test matches, [[Jacques Kallis]] holds the record for the highest number of awards won, with 23 in 166 matches played.<ref name = "test motm"/> In ODIs, [[Sachin Tendulkar]] holds the record for the highest number of man of the match titles, with 62 awards in 463 matches played.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://stats.espncricinfo.com/ci/content/records/283705.html |title=Records / One-Day Internationals / Individual records (captains, players, umpires) /Most player-of-the-match awards |work=ESPN Cricinfo |publisher=ESPN Sports Media |accessdate=2 January 2014 |date= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140304055509/http://stats.espncricinfo.com/ci/content/records/283705.html |archivedate=4 March 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Tendulkar is followed by [[Sanath Jayasuriya]], who, along with [[Ricky Ponting]], also holds the record for the most Man of the Match titles as captain.<ref>{{cite web|title=Records / One-Day Internationals / Individual records (captains, players, umpires) / Most player-of-the-match awards|url=http://stats.espncricinfo.com/ci/content/records/283705.html|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120902085726/http://stats.espncricinfo.com/ci/content/records/283705.html|archivedate=2 September 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In the shortest form of the game, [[T20 International]]s, this record is held by [[Shahid Afridi]], who has won 11 awards in 99 matches.
==Gaelic games==
In the Gaelic games of [[hurling]] and [[Gaelic football]], the "man of the match" ({{Lang-ga|Laoch na hImeartha}}<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.focloir.ie/en/dictionary/ei/man+of+the+match|title=man of the match - Translation to Irish Gaelic with audio pronunciation of translations for man of the match by New English-Irish Dictionary|website=www.focloir.ie|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170817205811/http://www.focloir.ie/en/dictionary/ei/man+of+the+match|archivedate=17 August 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>, "hero of the game") is commonly awarded after important games. An unusual example was the [[2008 All-Ireland Senior Hurling Championship Final]], where the award was given to [[Brian Cody]], the [[Kilkenny GAA|Kilkenny]] manager, rather than to a player.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hoganstand.com/ArticleForm.aspx?ID=100900|title=Bookie pays out on man of the match bets - Hoganstand.com|website=www.hoganstand.com|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170817204048/http://www.hoganstand.com/ArticleForm.aspx?ID=100900|archivedate=17 August 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In the women's sports of [[camogie]] and [[ladies' Gaelic football]], the term "player of the match" ({{Lang-ga|Laoch na hImeartha}}, "hero of the game") is used instead.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://clarechampion.ie/fiona-scoops-player-of-the-match-award/|title=Fiona scoops player of the match award – The Clare Champion|website=clarechampion.ie|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170817223801/http://clarechampion.ie/fiona-scoops-player-of-the-match-award/|archivedate=17 August 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.limerickpost.ie/2017/02/14/ul-repeat-ashbourne-supremacy-ucc/ereena-fryday-receives-her-player-of-the-match-award-from-catherine-neary-1222017/|title=Ereena Fryday receives her player of the match award from Catherine Neary 12/2/2017|publisher=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170817204538/http://www.limerickpost.ie/2017/02/14/ul-repeat-ashbourne-supremacy-ucc/ereena-fryday-receives-her-player-of-the-match-award-from-catherine-neary-1222017/|archivedate=17 August 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/gaelic-games/gaelic-football/shine-hails-impact-of-teen-star-odonoghue-36028640.html|title=Shine hails impact of teen star O'Donoghue - Independent.ie|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/2017/0812/896955-dublin-overcome-plucky-waterford-to-reach-final-four/|title=Dublin overcome plucky Waterford to reach final four|first=Jackie|last=Cahill|date=12 August 2017|publisher=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170817204024/https://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/2017/0812/896955-dublin-overcome-plucky-waterford-to-reach-final-four/|archivedate=17 August 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref> ==Ice hockey== {{main article|Three stars (ice hockey)}} In North American [[ice hockey]], the three players who perform best in the game, often either those who accumulate the most points or outstanding goaltenders, are usually designated the '''Three stars''' of the game: the top-performing player is the ''first star'', and so on. This tradition originated in the 1930s as a promotion for a "Three Star" brand of gasoline.<ref>[http://www.cbc.ca/sports/columns/top10/hockeygimmicks.html#threestars] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060615075333/http://www.cbc.ca/sports/columns/top10/hockeygimmicks.html|date=15 June 2006}}</ref>
However, in international play (and outside North America), the ''three stars'' concept is rarely used. Instead, other leagues may issue awards to one player who performed best in the game.
==Rugby football== Both codes of rugby, [[rugby league]] and [[rugby union]], commonly have man of the match or player of the match awards. In televised or sponsored matches, a commentator or sponsor often decides who gets the award, and it is presented to the winner after the match.
Examples of man of the match awards in professional men's rugby league are the [[Clive Churchill Medal]] in the [[National Rugby League Grand Final]], the [[Karyn Murphy Medal]] in the [[NRL Women's Premiership Grand Final]] the [[Lance Todd Trophy]] in the [[Challenge Cup]] final and the [[Harry Sunderland Trophy]] in the [[Super League Grand Final]].
==College basketball and football== In [[college basketball]] and [[college football]], the two collegiate sports with the most television coverage in the United States, a top player from each team is usually honoured as "players of the game." These athletes usually cannot collect material prizes due to [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] regulations. Instead, television companies broadcasting the game or corporate sponsors will often make donations to the scholarship funds of each school in the names of the winning players.{{cn|date=March 2018}}
In college basketball's Final Four events, a [[NCAA Basketball Tournament Most Outstanding Player|Most Outstanding Player]] award is given, for performance across both the semi-final and championship game. A Most Outstanding Player award is also given for each of the four regionals, based upon performances in the regional semifinals (Sweet Sixteen) and final (Elite Eight).
==Gridiron football== The [[National Football League]] names an MVP for two prominent games on its schedule: * A [[Super Bowl Most Valuable Player Award]] has been awarded at each [[Super Bowl]] (the NFL's championship). * The [[Pro Bowl]] has had an MVP award throughout its existence. The current Pro Bowl MVP format selects one offensive and one defensive player. From 1956–1971, two MVP awards were given, one to a [[skill position]] and the other to a [[lineman (American football)|lineman]] or [[linebacker]]. In 1972, an offensive and defensive MVP were named. From 1973–2012, a single Pro Bowl MVP was chosen.
Individual games typically have an informal player (or players) of the game chosen by the broadcast network covering the game; one prominent example of this phenomenon is the [[NFL on Thanksgiving Day#Game MVPs|Turkey Leg Award, All-Iron Award and Galloping Gobbler]] trophies awarded for games held on [[Thanksgiving (United States)|Thanksgiving]].
The [[Canadian Football League]] awards two MVP awards for its championship game, the [[Grey Cup]]. The [[Grey Cup Most Valuable Player]] award is open to all players; the [[Dick Suderman Trophy]] is limited to players with Canadian citizenship or who were raised in Canada since childhood.
==See also== *[[Best and fairest]] *[[Most Valuable Player]] *[[Most Outstanding Player (disambiguation)]] *[[Player of the year award]]

{{Infobox UK legislation |short_title = Protection of Wild Mammals (Scotland) Act 2002 |type = Act |parliament = Scottish Parliament |long_title = An Act of the Scottish Parliament to protect wild mammals from being hunted with dogs; and for connected purposes. |year = |citation = |introduced_by = [[Mike Watson, Baron Watson of Invergowrie|Mike Watson]] |territorial_extent = Scotland |si_made_date = |si_laid_date = |royal_assent = |commencement = 1 August 2002 |repeal_date = |replaces = |primary_legislation = |eu_directives = |amendments = |related_legislation = |repealing_legislation= |status = Current |original_text = |legislation_history = |use_new_UK-LEG = yes |UK-LEG_title = |revised_text = }} The '''Protection of Wild Mammals (Scotland) Act''' is an [[Act of the Scottish Parliament]] passed in February 2002, making [[Scotland]] the first part of the [[United Kingdom]] to ban traditional [[fox hunting]] and [[hare coursing]].
==Passage of the Act== The bill was introduced into the Scottish Parliament in 1999 by [[Mike Watson, Baron Watson of Invergowrie|Mike Watson]] MSP with support from SNP MSP [[Tricia Marwick]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/1816168.stm |title=Timeline: Scotland's fox hunting bill |work=BBC News |date=13 February 2002}}</ref> In September 2001, the Scottish Parliament rejected a negative committee report <ref>{{cite web |url=http://archive.parliament.scot/business/committees/historic/x-rural/reports-01/rar01-10-vol01-02.htm |title=Rural Development Committee. 10th Report 2001. Stage 1 Report on the Protection of Wild Mammals (Scotland) Bill. Volume 1 : Report |publisher=[[Scottish Parliament]] |date=2000 |accessdate=2 January 2016}}</ref> about the Bill from its Rural Development Committee and voted to support the general principles of the Bill.<ref>[http://www.scottish.parliament.uk/business/officialReports/meetingsParliament/or-01/sor0919-02.htm#Col2613]</ref> On 13 February 2002 the Parliament voted by eighty three to thirty six to pass the legislation to ban hunting with dogs.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/1819189.stm |title=Fox-hunting ban passed |work=BBC News |date=13 February 2002}}</ref><ref>[http://www.scottish.parliament.uk/business/officialReports/meetingsParliament/or-02/sor0213-02.htm#Col6513]</ref> [[Member of the Scottish Parliament|MSP]]s decided not to give compensation to those whose livelihoods or businesses might suffer as a result of the ban. The Scottish Countryside Alliance attempted to block introduction of the legislation by taking their case to the [[Court of Session]] in Edinburgh, although their appeal was not successful and in July the Judge recognised the will of the Parliament on this issue.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/2162766.stm |title=Court backs hunting ban |work=BBC News |date=31 July 2002}}</ref> The Act came into effect on 1 August 2002.
==Impact of the ban== An article in [[The Guardian]] on 9 September 2004 reports that of the ten Scottish hunts, nine survived the ban, using the permitted exemption allowing them to use packs of hounds to flush foxes to guns (an exemption which is strongly opposed by people against hunting).<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2004/sep/09/scotland.hunting |title=Legal rule helps hounds survive |first=Gerard |last=Seenan |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=9 September 2004 |accessdate=26 July 2015}}</ref>
A number of convictions have taken place under the Act, two for people hunting foxes and ten for hare coursing. The only prosecution of a traditional fox hunt led to a not guilty verdict, but to a clarification of the law, with the sheriff saying that the activity of flushing foxes to guns "will require to be accompanied by realistic and one would expect, effective arrangements for the shooting of pest species. The use of what might be termed "token guns" or what was described by the Crown as paying lip service to the legislation is not available ... as a justification for the continuation of what was referred to in the evidence before me as traditional fox hunting."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.scotcourts.gov.uk/search-judgments/judgment?id=6af686a6-8980-69d2-b500-ff0000d74aa7 |title=Judgement of Sheriff T A K Drummond, Q.C. in the cause Procurator Fiscal, Jedburgh Against Trevor Adams. Protection of Wild Mammals (Scotland) Act 2002 |publisher=Scottish Courts and Tribunals |date=10 December 2004 |accessdate=2 January 2016}}</ref>
There is controversy over the impact on the number of foxes killed by hunts. Hunts say that the number killed by hunts has doubled because shooting is more effective than chasing with dogs.
Since the ban 2 new fox hunts have started in Scotland, the Strathappin and the Dumfriesshire and Stewartry.
==2016 review== In December 2015, the Scottish Government announced that a review would be held that would look at legislation dealing with hunting with dogs, with the review to be led by [[Iain Bonomy, Lord Bonomy|Lord Bonomy]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-scotland-politics-35182347 |title=Lord Bonomy to lead review of Scottish fox hunting legislation |work=BBC News |date=26 December 2015}}</ref> In November 2016 a report was published with various recommendations, including making amendments to the law.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/nov/21/scottish-foxhunting-review-legislation |title=Scottish foxhunting review calls for stronger legislation |first=Libby |last=Brooks |work=The Guardian |date=21 November 2016 |accessdate=2 January 2016}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Animal law]] * [[Fox hunting legislation]] * [[Hunting Act 2004]]

{{more citations needed|date=May 2016}} {{Infobox civilian attack |title = Real Madrid Fan Club massacre |partof = the [[Iraqi Civil War (2014–present)]] |image = |caption = | map = {{Location map many | Iraq | width = 250 | float = right | label = Balad | marksize = 8 | lat_deg = 34 | lat_min = 0 | lon_deg = 44 | lon_min = 08 }} | map_size = | map_alt = | map_caption = Location of Balad, where the attacks took place, in Iraq. |location = [[Balad District, Iraq|Balad]], [[Iraq]] |target = [[Shia]] football fans |coordinates = |date = 13/29 May 2016 |time = |timezone = |type = [[Shooting]], [[suicide bombing]] |fatalities = '''Total:''' 28+ (+1 bomber)
* May 13: 16+ * May 29: 12+ (+1 bomber) |injuries = '''Total:''' 45+
* May 13: 30+ * May 29: 15+ |susperps = |perps = [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]] |weapons = [[AK-47]]s, bombs |motive = }} {{Campaignbox Iraq War (2014–present)}} On 13 May 2016, a group of militants armed with [[AK-47]]s attacked a cafe in [[Balad, Iraq]], frequented by supporters of the Spanish football club [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]].{{cite web|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/world-news/isis-kill-16-real-madrid-7962654|title=ISIS massacre 16 Real Madrid fans at supporters club|first=Stephen|last=Jones|date=13 May 2016|publisher=|accessdate=31 May 2016}} The [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]] (ISIL) claimed responsibility for the attack.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-36290195|title=IS militants attack Iraq cafe used by Real Madrid fans - BBC News|publisher=|accessdate=31 May 2016}} At least 16 people were killed and at least 30 were wounded. On 29 May 2016, ISIL gunmen and a suicide bomber attacked another Real Madrid fan club in the same area, killing at least 12 people and injuring around 15. They were attacked while watching the [[2016 UEFA Champions League Final]].{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-3615485/ISIS-gunmen-kill-12-Real-Madrid-fans-watch-Champions-League-Final-fresh-attack-club-s-supporters-Iraq.html|title=ISIS gunmen kill 12 Real Madrid fans as they watch Champions League|publisher=|accessdate=31 May 2016}} ==Events== During the first attack on May 13, around 50 fans of [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]] were gathered in a café in [[Balad, Iraq|Balad]], to discuss their arrangements for their favorite team's upcoming football match, when six armed men stormed into the café and started to shoot at the young men.{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/real-madrid-mourns-soccer-fans-killed-attack-cafe-iraq-n574026|title=Real Madrid Mourns Soccer Fans Killed in Attack on Cafe in Iraq|publisher=|accessdate=31 May 2016}} Reports claim that grenades were also used to attack those gathered to watch the match. Several attackers reportedly fled the cafe and then detonated themselves, one was captured but then burned to death.{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/05/13/isil-massacres-16-real-madrid-supporters-in-baghdad-caf/|title=Isil massacres 16 Real Madrid supporters in Iraq café|last=Farmer|first=Ben|date=2016-05-13|work=The Telegraph|access-date=2018-05-14|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}} At least 14 people were killed outright and two more died of their wounds later on. More than 30 people were injured.{{cite web|url=http://www.cbssports.com/soccer/news/real-madrid-players-pay-tribute-to-iraq-fan-club-members-killed-by-isis/|title=Real Madrid players pay tribute to Iraq fan club members killed by ISIS|publisher=|accessdate=31 May 2016}} ==Responsibility== Survivors of the attack blamed the attack on May 13 on ISIL and its opposition to football. In its claim of responsibility, ISIL said the attack had targeted [[Shia]] militiamen, making no mention of any connection to Real Madrid. Some believe that the claim stems from the extremist groups ideology against football, as they believe it is a product of western society.{{Cite news|url=https://www.thenational.ae/world/in-iraq-town-real-madrid-fans-gather-in-defiance-of-isil-1.192956|title=In Iraq town, Real Madrid fans gather in defiance of ISIL|work=The National|access-date=2018-05-14|language=en}} ==Reaction== The attack was condemned by soccer fans around the world.{{cite web|url=https://np.reddit.com/r/soccer/comments/4j6lun/isis_kill_14_real_madrid_fans/|title=ISIS kill 14 Real Madrid fans. • /r/soccer|publisher=|accessdate=31 May 2016}} [[Javier Tebas|Javier Tebas Medrano]] the President of Spain's [[La Liga]] responded to the attack with the statement "Terrorism has attacked football. We are with the victims and their families." The [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]] football club itself expressed "great sadness" and offered its "regards and condolences" to the families and friends of the victims.{{cite web|url=http://www.realmadrid.com/en/news/2016/05/official-announcement|title=Official Announcement - Real Madrid CF|publisher=|accessdate=31 May 2016}} Real Madrid players wore black armbands for their away game against [[Deportivo de La Coruña]], on [[2015-16 La Liga|14 May 2016]], as a mark of respect.{{cite web|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11835/10281131/real-madrid-players-to-wear-black-armbands.-as-a-mark-of-respect-for-iraq-massacre|title=Real Madrid players to wear black armbands as a mark of respect for Iraq massacre|accessdate=13 May 2016}} The team also honoured the victims by observing a moment of silence before their match. On May 28, 2016 family and friends of victims gathered at the cafe to watch the game, surrounded by armed police, frisking those who attempted to enter the cafe.{{Cite news|url=https://www.thesun.co.uk/archives/football/1222615/real-madrid-fans-where-16-were-killed-by-gunmen-in-isis-massacre-break-down-in-tears-after-champions-league-win/|title=Real Madrid fans where 16 were killed by gunmen in ISIS massacre break down in tears after win|date=2016-05-29|work=The Sun|access-date=2018-05-14|language=en-GB}} After the second attack, [[Florentino Pérez]], the club president, dedicated Real Madrid's win to the fans that were killed, and other Iraqi club fans, including those killed by ISIS.[http://vestnikkavkaza.net/news/Real-Madrid-s-Florentino-Perez-dedicates-Champions-League-victory-to-Iraqi-fans-killed-by-Daesh.html Real Madrid's Florentino Perez dedicates Champions League victory to Iraqi fans killed by Daesh] Alaa al-Hashemi, the Iraqi ambassador to [[Spain]], thanked the club and invited the president to visit [[Iraq]].{{cite web|url=http://www.iraqinews.com/iraq-war/iraq-thanks-real-madrid-calls-chairman-visit-baghdad/|title=Iraq thanks Real Madrid and invites its chairman to visit Baghdad - Iraqi News|first=Abdelhak|last=Mamoun|date=30 May 2016|publisher=|accessdate=31 May 2016}} ==See also== *[[11 May 2016 Baghdad bombings]] *[[List of terrorist incidents, January–June 2016]] *[[Terrorist incidents in Iraq in 2016]] *[[Borussia Dortmund team bus bombing]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Portal bar|2010s|Iraq|Terrorism}} {{Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant}} {{coord missing|Iraq}} [[Category:ISIL terrorist incidents in Iraq]] [[Category:Massacres in 2016]] [[Category:Massacres in Iraq]] [[Category:Real Madrid C.F.]] [[Category:Terrorist incidents in Iraq in 2016]] [[Category:Islamic terrorist incidents in 2016]] [[Category:May 2016 crimes]] [[Category:Politics and sports]] [[Category:Balad, Iraq]] [[Category:May 2016 events in Asia]] [[Category:Sports-related accidents and incidents]]

{{inline|date=October 2014}} [[Image:RPWlogo.jpg|thumb|right|150px|'''Real Pro Wrestling''''s Logo.]] '''Real Pro Wrestling''' (also known as '''RPW''' or '''RealPro Wrestling''') was a [[professional]] [[sports league]] of [[wrestling]], similar to the [[amateur wrestling]] found in the [[Olympic Games]] and at the [[collegiate wrestling|college]] and [[scholastic wrestling|high school]] level. The term "real" was meant to emphasize that it was [[professional]] (meaning the wrestlers are paid money) and it was wrestling, but that it was not [[professional wrestling]] in the traditional sense; modern professional wrestling features [[work (professional wrestling)|predetermined outcomes]] and operates under a very different [[Professional wrestling#Rules|set of rules]] from amateur wrestling.
Real Pro Wrestling, Inc was founded in 2002 by former [[Northwestern University]] wrestling teammates Toby Willis and Matt Case. The company was based in [[Nashville, Tennessee]] with branch offices in New York and Virginia. RPW was a television production company and a producer of live events.
The league began operations in March 2005 and consisted of eight teams (see below). Although the teams had various city and state names, all matches were taped on a soundstage in Nashville and Los Angeles (Los Angeles Center Studios).
According to [https://web.archive.org/web/20050126155145/http://realprowrestling.com/ the official website], "In RPW, classic meets the future as the matches are conducted in a specially designed coliseum which showcases a raised circular mat to facilitate better camera angles and to afford the live audience a better viewing experience. The circular mat allows for 360 degree camera angles and aids in covering the close quarters that wrestlers frequently find themselves in as they maneuver for position."
Numerous similar projects were announced before RPW, but none had gotten off the ground. Lanny Bryant, the [[Montana]]-based editor of ''Wrestling USA'' magazine, proposed a similar league in the early 1990s, as one example.
RPW folded in 2007, after two seasons (2004 and 2006-7).
In the spring of 2013, the Association of Career Wrestlers formed a new series offering competitions with financial incentives for post-collegiate wrestlers called [http://touracw.com Tour ACW]. This new series has a new set of rules building on the RPW rules with an emphasis on scoring.<ref>http://www.intermatwrestle.com/articles/11869</ref>
==Wrestling style== The style of wrestling that is used in ''RPW'' is a combination of [[Freestyle wrestling|freestyle]], [[folkstyle|American Folkstyle]], [[Sumo|sumo wrestling]] and [[Greco-Roman wrestling]]. Because of this, wrestlers of many styles competed in the league. Greco-Roman and Freestyle were the most common wrestling backgrounds in the leagues, due largely to the Olympic experience of the wrestlers in the league. In fact, the team rosters consists of numerous Olympians and [[NCAA]] champions.
==Rules== The rules were similar to [[Freestyle wrestling#Scoring|freestyle wrestling]] but were modified to encourage risk and intensity. The goal is to dominate the opponent and pin his shoulders to the mat. This is called a fall. Points are also awarded during the six-minute match for controlling the opponent, placing him in danger, or escaping the opponent's control. If there is no fall, then the wrestler with the most points wins the match. Some of the most noticeable changes were as follows: # Two 3-minute periods instead of 3 periods totaling 7 minutes # If a wrestler pushed his opponent out of the ring he would get a point. # '''The Bonus''' - if a wrestler manages to stay in the center of the mat and stay aggressive, their ''bonus meter'' would go up. If they got the bonus, they would get to go into a special position in which they couldn't lose any points and could gain points by throwing their opponents. # '''TV Challenge''' - the coach of each wrestler is allowed once per individual match to challenge a call made by the ''Ref'' using video from multiple video angles.
==Teams== *California Claw *Chicago Groove *Iowa Stalkers *Minnesota Freeze *New York Outrage *Oklahoma Slam *Pennsylvania Hammer *Texas Shooters
==League structure== Despite the existence of eight "franchises" in RPW, all tournaments were conducted in a classic elimination bracket format. No actual [[dual meet]]s were held.
==Television coverage== In the league's first season, 2005–06, matches were televised on PAX TV (now [[ION Television]]) on Sunday evenings and on [[Fox Sports Net]] affiliates at various times. [[Rulon Gardner]], one of the most famous figures in amateur wrestling in the [[United States]], was the [[color analyst]]. Veteran Radio and Television Sports Announcer Chip Hoback from Nashville, TN did the Voice Over and Highlights.
Due to executive reorganizations at both networks, both PAX and FSN pulled the show. RPW then decided to syndicate coverage of the second season on various [[terrestrial television|broadcast stations]].
In an [http://thewrestlingmall.com/stories/rpw_willis_interview.php interview] with [http://www.thewrestlingmall.com/ The Wrestling Mall] co-founder Toby Willis also revealed that although sponsors and investors were already lined up for Season 2 a few employees had attempted a "take over" of the company which also added to the downfall of the league. In the same series of articles Mr. Willis stated his wish that wrestling would adopt more of a martial arts mentality to draw in more kids. Mr. Willis said, "Wrestling desperately needs to rebrand itself as a martial art not just another arbitrary sport. We need to use military terminology and martial art vocabulary. We need to teach it as self defense. So instead of the high school coach walking up to a kid in the hallways of school and asking them to try wrestling, they should ask the kid if he wants to learn self defense. What kid says they want to be defenseless? Then when the kid shows up for practice, the coach has to teach wrestling from a martial arts perspective."
==Notable participants==
*[[Muhammed Lawal]] - Season 1 Champion, NCAA Division II champion and Freestyle World Championships competitor (7th place), current mixed martial artist with [[Bellator MMA|Bellator]], and former [[List of Strikeforce champions#Light Heavyweight Championship|Strikeforce Light Heavyweight Champion]]. *[[Andy Hrovat]] - wrestled at [[2008 Olympics]] and defeated Muhammed Lawal at the 2008 U.S. Olympic Trials. *[[Daniel Cormier]] - Season 1 Champion, two-time Olympic Freestyle Wrestler and 2008 U.S. team captain, King of the Cage Champion, Strikeforce Heavyweight Grand Prix Champion and the current [[Ultimate Fighting Championship|UFC]] light heavyweight, and heavyweight champion. *[[Teague Moore]] - U.S. Open Champion, College Wrestling Coach, & Founder of the Association of Career Wrestlers. *[[Aaron Simpson (fighter)|Aaron Simpson]] - 11 [[Ultimate Fighting Championship|UFC]] veteran, competing in both the Middle Weight and Welterweight division. Also a former competitor on [[American Gladiators]]. *[[Joe Warren (fighter)|Joe Warren]] - 2006 Greco-Roman World Championships gold medalist, current mixed martial artist with [[Bellator Fighting Championships]], and [[List_of_Bellator_champions#Bellator Tournaments|Bellator Season 2 Featherweight Tournament]] winner and former [[List_of_Bellator_champions#Featherweight Championship|Bellator Featherweight Champion]]. *[[Patrick Cummins (fighter)|Patrick Cummins]] (born November 16, 1980) is an American mixed martial artist.[5] He currently competes in the Light Heavyweight division of the Ultimate Fighting Championship. As of August 3, 2015, Cummins is #12 in official UFC Light Heavyweight rankings. [6]
