Some believe it salutes military and police officers who have died on duty; for others, it honors the United States generally.<ref name=":2">{{cite news|last= Brady|first= Erik|title= How national anthem became essential part of sports|url= https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/nfl/2017/09/26/how-national-anthem-become-essential-part-sports/706243001/|newspaper= USA Today|date= September 27, 2017|accessdate= June 5, 2018|language= en}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1= Har|first1= Janie|last2= Contreras|first2= Russell|title= Diverse America divided on flag, anthem, other symbols|date= September 16, 2016|publisher= Associated Press|url= https://apnews.com/1959daeed38b466395f053f6f9b2dc52/diverse-america-divided-flag-anthem-other-symbols|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20171207181301/https://apnews.com/1959daeed38b466395f053f6f9b2dc52/diverse-america-divided-flag-anthem-other-symbols|archivedate= December 7, 2017|deadurl= no}}</ref> Between 2012 and 2015, the [[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]] gave $6.8 million to teams across all major sports in exchange for holding various military and patriotic events at their games, including the performance of the national anthem.<ref name=":5" /><ref>{{Cite web|url= https://www.mccain.senate.gov/public/_cache/files/12de6dcb-d8d8-4a58-8795-562297f948c1/tackling-paid-patriotism-oversight-report.pdf|title= Tackling Paid Patriotism|last= McCain|first= John|last2= Flake|first2= Jeff|date= 2015|website= |archive-url= |archive-date= |dead-url= |access-date= }}</ref>
Kaepernick and his 49ers teammate [[Eric Reid (American football)|Eric Reid]] say they choose to kneel during the anthem to call attention to the issues of racial inequality and police brutality. "After hours of careful consideration, and even a visit from [[Nate Boyer]], a retired [[Special Forces (United States Army)|Green Beret]] and former NFL player, we came to the conclusion that we should kneel, rather than sit, ... during the anthem as a peaceful protest," said Reid. "We chose to kneel because it's a [[respect]]ful gesture. I remember thinking our posture was like a flag flown at half-mast to mark a tragedy."<ref>{{cite news|last= Reid|first= Eric|title= Opinion {{!}} Eric Reid: Why Colin Kaepernick and I Decided to Take a Knee|url= https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/25/opinion/colin-kaepernick-football-protests.html|newspaper= [[The New York Times]]|date= September 25, 2017|access-date= September 27, 2017|language= en-US|issn= 0362-4331}}</ref> Some regard kneeling as disrespectful to those who have died or been wounded in service of the United States, such as police officers or military veterans.<ref>{{cite news|last= MacQuarrie|first= Brian|title= Military veterans divided over NFL protests|url= https://www.bostonglobe.com/metro/2017/09/25/military/MLjykBWSTbMlWqbaVUAGzI/story.html|newspaper= The Boston Globe|date= September 27, 2017|access-date= June 5, 2018}}</ref> Torrey Smith, a wide receiver for the Philadelphia Eagles, said in an interview: "I understand why people are offended by people protesting the National Anthem. My father served 25 years. When he dies, he's going to be wrapped in an American flag. But my dad is also out of the Army, and he drives trucks all over the country, and he's a black man everywhere he goes, and sometimes he has racial incidents still today. That doesn't protect him, just because he served our country. And I think that's important."<ref> {{Cite news|url= https://www.cnn.com/2017/09/27/us/nfl-anthem-protest-race-trump-trnd/index.html|title= The #TakeAKnee protests have always been about race. Period.|last= CNN|first= AJ Willingham,|work= CNN|access-date= 2018-06-18}} </ref>
== Reasons for the protest and related charity == [[Criminal justice reform in the United States|Criminal justice reform]] is one of the top issues that NFL players have been supporting in their protests.<ref>{{cite news|last=Reid|first=Jason|title=NFL owners, players are moving in the wrong direction|date=October 30, 2017|work=The Undefeated|url=https://theundefeated.com/features/nfl-owners-players-are-moving-in-the-wrong-direction/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171030163548/https://theundefeated.com/features/nfl-owners-players-are-moving-in-the-wrong-direction/|archivedate=October 30, 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref> Kaepernick was initially moved to protest by the deaths of African Americans at the hands of police or while in police custody. These deaths gained prominence through the media and the [[Black Lives Matter]] movement in the years immediately preceding the protest.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/jurisprudence/2016/10/ruth_bader_ginsburg_s_kaepernick_comments_end_the_notorious_rbg_myth.html|title=Ruth Bader Ginsburg Was Never Really "Notorious RBG"|last=Stern|first=Mark Joseph|date=October 11, 2016|work=Slate|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.slate.com%2Farticles%2Fnews_and_politics%2Fjurisprudence%2F2016%2F10%2Fruth_bader_ginsburg_s_kaepernick_comments_end_the_notorious_rbg_myth.html&date=2017-09-27|archivedate=September 27, 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref> During a post-game interview on August 26, 2016, he stated, "I am not going to stand up to show pride in a flag for a country that oppresses black people and [[people of color]]. To me, this is bigger than football and it would be selfish on my part to look the other way. There are bodies in the street and people getting paid leave and getting away with murder", adding that he would continue to protest during the anthem until he feels like "[the United States flag] represents what it's supposed to represent."<ref name="wyche">{{cite web|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000691077/article/colin-kaepernick-explains-protest-of-national-anthem|title=Colin Kaepernick explains why he sat during national anthem|last=Wyche|first=Steve|date=August 27, 2016|publisher=National Football League|accessdate=August 27, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/09/18/colin-kaepernick-nfl-black-lives-matter-protests-recall-rebellio/|title=Colin Kaepernick: NFL Black Lives Matter protests recall rebellious spirit of 1960s sporting greats|author=Nick Allen|date=September 18, 2016|website=The Daily Telegraph|accessdate=November 8, 2016}}</ref>
After that interview, Kaepernick pledged to donate the first $1 million of his $11.9 million salary from the 2016–2017 season to different organizations that help communities in need.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbssports.com/nfl/news/colin-kaepernick-says-hell-donate-1-million-to-charities-that-help-communities-in-need/|title=Colin Kaepernick to donate $1 million to charities that aid communities in need|last1=Wagner-McGough|first1=Sean|date=September 2, 2016|publisher=cbssports.com|accessdate=October 17, 2016}}</ref> He pledged to donate $100,000 per month for 10 months to various organizations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ninerswire.usatoday.com/2016/09/20/colin-kaepernick-to-donate-100k-a-month-for-10-months/|title=Colin Kaepernick to donate $100k a month for 10 months|last1=Biderman|first1=Chris|work=USA Today|format=September 20, 2016|accessdate=October 17, 2016}}</ref> Days later, the [[San Francisco 49ers]] matched Kaepernick by pledging $1 million to two organizations addressing racial and social inequality.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/sports/nfl/la-sp-colin-kaepernick-49ers-donation-20160908-snap-story.html|title=49ers to donate $1 million to charities that focus on racial issues cited by Colin Kaepernick|last1=Loumena|first1=Dan|date=September 9, 2016|work=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=October 17, 2016}}</ref> Kaepernick has been following through on his commitment and has donated $900,000 as of September 2017 to groups including [[Meals on Wheels]], United We Dream, Black Veterans for Social Justice and many others.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://ftw.usatoday.com/2017/08/colin-kaepernick-nfl-national-anthem-protest-one-million-dollar-pledge-donations-empower-communities|title=Colin Kaepernick has donated $800k to empower oppressed communities|date=August 23, 2017|work=For The Win|access-date=September 27, 2017|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/maurybrown/2017/09/15/dont-ignore-this-positive-pr-twist-to-colin-kaepernick/#77a7a1d35740|title=Don't Ignore This Positive PR Twist To Colin Kaepernick|last=Brown|first=Maury|work=Forbes|access-date=September 27, 2017|language=en}}</ref> Kaepernick has also held "Know Your Rights" camps for young [[People of Color|people of color]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://knowyourrightscamp.com/about/|title=About Us – Know Your Rights Camp|website=knowyourrightscamp.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-11-01}}</ref> The camps include legal education from attorneys that give advice on how to interact with police when being detained and lectures from prominent academics on the history of the [[Civil Rights Movement]] in the United States.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thenation.com/article/colin-kaepernicks-message-to-chicago-youth-know-your-rights/|title=Colin Kaepernick's Message to Chicago Youth: 'Know Your Rights'|last=Zirin|first=Dave|date=May 10, 2017|work=The Nation|access-date=September 27, 2017|issn=0027-8378}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/early-lead/wp/2016/10/30/colin-kaepernick-holds-know-your-rights-camp-for-underprivileged-bay-area-kids/|title=Colin Kaepernick holds 'Know Your Rights' camp for underprivileged Bay Area kids|last=Bieler|first=Des|date=October 30, 2016|work=Washington Post|access-date=September 27, 2017|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref> The [[National Football League Players Association]] (NFLPA) named Kaepernick the Week One MVP in September 2017 for his charity work related to the protest.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/early-lead/wp/2017/09/15/nfl-players-union-names-colin-kaepernick-its-week-1-mvp-for-his-charity-work/|title=NFL players' union names Colin Kaepernick its Week 1 MVP for his charity work|last=Payne|first=Marissa|date=September 15, 2017|work=Washington Post|access-date=September 27, 2017|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref>
=== Trump calls for firing protesting players=== {{see also|Protests against Donald Trump}} [[File:Donald Trump with jersey, helmet and football of New England Patriots.jpg|thumb|President Trump meeting with the players and staff of [[New England Patriots]] at the [[White House]] on April 19, 2017 following their [[Super Bowl LI]] win over the [[Atlanta Falcons]].]] In September 2017, U.S. President [[Donald Trump]], speaking at a rally in Huntsville, Alabama, said NFL owners should fire players who kneel during the national anthem, and encouraged fans to walk out. Trump tried to use his position at the administration to advise NFL owners to say "Get that son of a bitch off the field right now, out, he's fired. He's fired!"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://money.cnn.com/2017/09/23/media/donald-trump-nfl-protest-backlash/index.html|title=With 'son of a bitch' comments, Trump tried to divide NFL and its players|last=Stelter|first=Brian}}</ref> Trump called the players' protest "a total disrespect of our heritage".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2017/09/22/trump-nfl-protests-football-243046|title=Trump sparks war with NFL – and LeBron|last=Griffiths|first=Brent D.|date=September 22, 2017|access-date=September 23, 2017|publisher=[[Politico]]|last2=Jackson|first2=Henry C.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/trump-to-nfl-owners-fire-players-who-kneel-during-national-anthem/|title=Trump to NFL owners: Fire players who kneel during national anthem|date=September 23, 2017|publisher=CBS News}}</ref> He went on to say that new NFL safety rules meant to protect players from [[Concussions in American football|concussions]] are ruining the game for the public.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/early-lead/wp/2017/09/26/congresswoman-trump-endangering-nfl-players-with-reckless-comments-about-safety/|title=Congresswoman: Trump endangering NFL players with 'reckless' comments about safety|last=Payne|first=Marissa|date=September 26, 2017|work=Washington Post|access-date=September 27, 2017|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref> His statement came after new research indicates NFL players are at high risk for [[chronic traumatic encephalopathy]] (CTE) due to the likelihood of multiple head injuries.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/2017/07/25/539198429/study-cte-found-in-nearly-all-donated-nfl-player-brains|title=Study: CTE Found In Nearly All Donated NFL Player Brains|work=NPR.org|access-date=September 27, 2017|language=en}}</ref>
Trump denied his criticism of the protesters was related to race. "This has to do with respect for our country and respect for our flag," he said.<ref>{{cite news|first1=Bryan Armen|last1=Graham|first2=Martin|last2=Pengelly|title=NFL players kneel for anthem in unprecedented defiance of Trump|date=September 24, 2017|newspaper=The Guardian|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/sep/24/donald-trump-nfl-protests-kneel-anthem|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171026045803/https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/sep/24/donald-trump-nfl-protests-kneel-anthem|archivedate=October 26, 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref> In the games immediately following Trump's statements, the protest gained broader participation when over 200 players sat or knelt during the anthem, others linked arms with their teammates or raised fists, and three teams chose to stay in the locker room for the anthem.<ref name=":3" /><ref name="SB" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":4">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/24/sports/nfl-trump-anthem-protests.html|title=After Trump Blasts N.F.L., Players Kneel and Lock Arms in Solidarity|last=Hoffman|first=Benjamin|date=September 24, 2017|work=The New York Times|access-date=September 27, 2017|last2=Mather|first2=Victor|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331|last3=Fortin|first3=Jacey}}</ref> However, the response was more a reaction to Trump than Kaepernick's original protests of racial injustice.<ref name=":4"/><ref name="latimes.com">{{cite news|last1=Farmer|first1=Sam|last2=King|first2=Laura|title=As Trump continues his attacks, NFL players protest by kneeling or locking arms|date=September 24, 2017|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|url=http://www.latimes.com/sports/nfl/la-sp-nfl-players-protest-trump-20170924-story.html|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.latimes.com%2Fsports%2Fnfl%2Fla-sp-nfl-players-protest-trump-20170924-story.html&date=2017-09-29|archivedate=September 29, 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Jones|first=Jonathan|title=A Gesture of Support by NFL Owners Is Meaningless without Them Taking Real Action|date=September 26, 2017|website=SI.com|url=https://www.si.com/nfl/2017/09/26/nfl-anthem-protests-team-owners-shad-khan-dan-snyder|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.si.com%2Fnfl%2F2017%2F09%2F26%2Fnfl-anthem-protests-team-owners-shad-khan-dan-snyder&date=2017-09-29|archivedate=September 29, 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref> Reasons cited by players, owners, and coaches included supporting freedom of speech and opposing what they considered intimidation by Trump.<ref name=":4" /> Others said they took offense to Trump demeaning the integrity of their primarily African American colleagues, when a month earlier he had called the [[white nationalists]] who [[Unite the Right rally|protested in Charlottesville, Virginia]], "Very fine people".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.sbnation.com/2017/9/23/16354502/donald-trump-nfl-players-reactions-national-anthem-protests-twitter|title=NFL players respond with heat to Donald Trump's comments about protests|work=SBNation.com|access-date=September 27, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/nfl-eric-reid-donald-trump-race-row-neo-nazis-charlottesville-fine-people-president-us-latest-a7967811.html|title=NFL player who started anti-Trump movement: 'He refers to us with slurs but Charlottesville neo-Nazis as 'very fine people'|date=September 26, 2017|work=The Independent|access-date=September 27, 2017|language=en-GB}}</ref> The reaction to Trump's remarks overshadowed other ongoing issues his administration was facing, including failed [[American Health Care Act of 2017|attempts at healthcare reform]], the primary election loss of Trump-backed candidate [[Luther Strange]] for the [[United States Senate special election in Alabama, 2017|Alabama seat in the U.S. Senate]], recovery efforts for [[Hurricane Maria]] in Puerto Rico and [[Hurricane Harvey]] in [[Houston]], and [[North Korea–United States relations|relations with North Korea]] over their [[2017 North Korean nuclear test|nuclear]] and [[2017 North Korean missile tests|missile testing]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Donald Trump fuels NFL anthem row by tweeting year old video|date=October 1, 2017|newspaper=The Telegraph|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/10/01/donald-trump-fuels-nfl-anthem-row-tweeting-year-old-video/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171001063651/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/10/01/donald-trump-fuels-nfl-anthem-row-tweeting-year-old-video/|archivedate=October 1, 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref>
Many players beyond the 2017 season have knelt or raised fists in protest against the policies of President [[Donald Trump]].<ref name=":4"/><ref name="latimes.com"/>
In May 2018 on an in interview President Donald Trump went as far to say "You have to stand proudly for the national anthem, or you shouldn’t be playing, you shouldn’t be there. Maybe you shouldn’t be in the country".<ref name="nbcnews.com">https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/donald-trump/trump-says-nfl-players-who-kneel-during-national-anthem-maybe-n876996</ref> He went from his previous opinion that these NFL players should be fired to that they should "maybe" be deported. Trump applauded the new policy that NFL players must either stand for the anthem or stay back in the locker room, but felt that this policy was not strict enough. <ref name="nbcnews.com"/> Trump even wanted players to not be able to express political views even when off the field. <ref name="nbcnews.com"/>
==NFL protests==
===2016 preseason=== Kaepernick began sitting during the national anthem at the start of the 2016 NFL preseason. His actions went unnoticed for two weeks before he was questioned by the media.<ref>{{cite news|last=Levin|first=Josh|title=Colin Kaepernick's Protest Is Working|date=September 12, 2016|work=Slate|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/sports/sports_nut/2016/09/colin_kaepernick_s_protest_is_working.html|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.slate.com%2Farticles%2Fsports%2Fsports_nut%2F2016%2F09%2Fcolin_kaepernick_s_protest_is_working.html&date=2017-09-27|archivedate=September 27, 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref> In the 49ers' final 2016 preseason game on September 1, 2016, after talking to Boyer, Kaepernick opted to kneel during the U.S. national anthem rather than sit as he did in their previous games. He explained his decision to switch was an attempt to show more respect to former and current U.S. military members while still protesting during the anthem. [[Eric Reid (American football)|Eric Reid]] joined Kaepernick in kneeling during the national anthem during the final preseason game.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/sep/01/colin-kaepernick-eric-reid-kneel-national-anthem-protest-san-francisco-49ers|title=Colin Kaepernick joined by Eric Reid in kneeling for national anthem protest|last=Press|first=Associated|date=September 1, 2016|newspaper=The Guardian|issn=0261-3077|access-date=September 7, 2016}}</ref> [[Seattle Seahawks]] player [[Jeremy Lane]] also did not stand for the anthem during his final preseason game the same day, stating, "It's something I plan to keep on doing until justice is being served."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/nfl/seahawks/2016/09/01/jeremy-lane-colin-kaepernick-national-anthem-protest/89752460/|title=Seahawks' Jeremy Lane joins Colin Kaepernick's protest, sits during national anthem|access-date=September 7, 2016}}</ref>
===2016 season=== In Week 1, eleven NFL players joined Kaepernick's protests.<ref name="breech">{{cite web|last1=Breech|first1=John|title=Here are the 11 players who joined Colin Kaepernick's protest in Week 1|url=http://www.cbssports.com/nfl/news/here-are-the-11-players-who-joined-colin-kaepernicks-protest-in-week-1/|publisher=CBS News|accessdate=September 20, 2016}}</ref> [[Denver Broncos]] player [[Brandon Marshall (linebacker)|Brandon Marshall]] knelt during the national anthem prior to the start of the [[National Football League Kickoff game|Kickoff game]], which was broadcast on [[NBC Sunday Night Football|NBC]].<ref name="money">{{cite web|last1=Scott|first1=Nate|title=Broncos linebacker Brandon Marshall takes knee during national anthem|url=http://ftw.usatoday.com/2016/09/broncos-brandon-marshall-takes-knee-national-anthem-colin-kaepernick|work=USA Today|accessdate=September 20, 2016}}</ref> The act of kneeling as protest has been referred to as "taking a knee".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/what-the-nfl-take-a-knee-protests-mean/2017/09/26/4915930e-a210-11e7-b573-8ec86cdfe1ed_story.html|title=Opinion {{!}} What the NFL take-a-knee protests mean|website=Washington Post|access-date=2017-10-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2017/09/30/us/costas-nfl-cnntv/index.html|title=Bob Costas: Stand for anthem, then take a knee|last=CNN|first=Alexandra King,|work=CNN|access-date=2017-10-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/taking-a-knee-national-anthem-nfl-trump-why-meaning-origins-racism-us-colin-kaepernick-a7966961.html|title=All you need to know about why NFL players are taking a knee and where it came from|date=2017-09-25|work=The Independent|access-date=2017-10-03|language=en-GB}}</ref> Kaepernick and Marshall were teammates at the [[University of Nevada]].<ref name="money"/> On September 11, [[Kansas City Chiefs]] player [[Marcus Peters]] [[raised fist|raised his fist]] while the rest of the team interlocked their arms showing solidarity.<ref name="time">{{cite news|last1=Gajanan|first1=Mahita|title=Kansas City Chiefs Cornerback Marcus Peters Raises Fist During National Anthem|url=http://time.com/4486853/kansas-city-chiefs-marcus-peters-national-anthem/|work=Time|accessdate=September 20, 2016}}</ref> Two members of the [[New England Patriots]], [[Devin McCourty]] and [[Martellus Bennett]], raised their fists on ''[[NBC Sunday Night Football|Sunday Night Football]]''. The entire Seattle Seahawks team stood and interlocked arms.<ref name="arnold">{{cite web|last1=Arnold|first1=Geoffrey|title=Seattle Seahawks lock arms during national anthem|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/nfl/index.ssf/2016/09/seattle_seahawks_lock_arms_dur.html|work=The Oregonian|accessdate=September 20, 2016}}</ref> [[Jelani Jenkins]], [[Arian Foster]], [[Kenny Stills]], and [[Michael Thomas (defensive back)|Michael Thomas]] of the [[Miami Dolphins]] all knelt during the National Anthem.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ajc.com/sports/miami-dolphins-kneel-during-national-anthem/tVERFq0ty4uFmEqT2ULKCL/|title=4 Miami Dolphins kneel during national anthem|first=Hal|last=Habib|website=ajc}}</ref> At the same time, a group of [[Jacksonville Jaguars]] players, led by cornerback [[Prince Amukamara]], initially planned to join the protest but chose not to do so after photographs of Kaepernick wearing socks with a crude anti-police message during training camp were made public.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/blog/jacksonville-jaguars/post/_/id/19870/jaguars-players-considered-protest-but-pig-socks-derailed-plans|title=Jaguars players considered protest, but pig socks scuttled plans|accessdate=December 16, 2016}}</ref>
On November 13, 2016, 5 days after [[Donald Trump]] was [[United States presidential election, 2016|elected]] [[President of the United States|President]], [[Tampa Bay Buccaneers]] wide-receiver [[Mike Evans (wide receiver)|Mike Evans]] decided to sit during the national anthem. According to ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'', Evans said, "If this happens, then America's not right right now. I said this a long time ago. When he ran, I thought it was a joke, and the joke continues. I'm not a political person that much, but I got common sense. And I know when something's not right."<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.cbssports.com/nfl/news/mike-evans-sat-during-anthem-to-protest-donald-trump-presidency/ |title=Mike Evans sat during anthem to protest Donald Trump presidency |publisher=CBSSports.com |access-date=November 27, 2016}}</ref> However, his protest began the day following [[Veterans Day]], so he received criticism. He quickly changed his method of protesting and joined his teammates during the following game against the Kansas City Chiefs. He apologized to veterans and other members of the military for his actions – citing that the timing of his protest was poor. "On the field, I'm going to continue to do what I do – play hard. I'm playing hard because I've got this right – freedom, because of the vets. I'm going to reach out to organizations, organizations that I feel are doing the best job to help the minority ... women, LGBT, African Americans, Latinos, people that are in fear of Donald Trump and his presidency."<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.espn.com/blog/tampa-bay-buccaneers/post/_/id/15124/bucs-mike-evans-stands-for-national-anthem |title=Bucs' Mike Evans ends protest, stands for national anthem |publisher=ESPN |access-date=November 27, 2016}}</ref>
===2017 season=== [[File:Oakland Raiders National Anthem Kneeling (37444579735).jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|Oakland Raiders players [[kneeling]] in week{{nbsp}}3]] [[Cleveland Browns]] tight end [[Seth DeValve]] became the first white football player to kneel or sit during the anthem on the team's August 21, 2017 preseason game against the [[New York Giants]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadspin.com/seth-devalve-is-the-first-white-player-to-kneel-for-the-1798295618|title=Seth DeValve Is The First White Player To Kneel for the National Anthem|last=Baccellieri|first=Emma}}</ref> [[File:Washington Redskins National Anthem Kneeling (37301887651) (cropped).jpg|thumb|upright=1.85|Washington Redskins players kneeling before the game with the Oakland Raiders]] [[File:San Francisco 49ers National Anthem Kneeling (37721041581).jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|Members of the San Francisco 49ers kneeling during the National Anthem before a game against the Washington Redskins in week 6]] <!-- See talk page for a discussion regarding this list. --> In Week 3 of the season the majority of games were played two days after Trump made his statements.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Graham|first1=Bryan|title=Donald Trump blasts NFL anthem protesters: 'Get that son of a bitch off the field'|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2017/sep/22/donald-trump-nfl-national-anthem-protests|website=theguardian|publisher=Guardian News|accessdate=3 October 2017}}</ref> The protest gained broader participation when over 200 players sat or knelt during the anthem.<ref name=":1" /><ref name="SB" /><ref name=":3">{{cite news|title=Cowboys are one of six NFL teams that haven't had a player kneel, sit or raise a fist during national anthem|date=September 25, 2017|newspaper=The Dallas Morning News|url=https://sportsday.dallasnews.com/dallas-cowboys/cowboys/2017/09/25/cowboys-one-six-nfl-teams-player-kneel-sit-national-anthem|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=https%3A%2F%2Fsportsday.dallasnews.com%2Fdallas-cowboys%2Fcowboys%2F2017%2F09%2F25%2Fcowboys-one-six-nfl-teams-player-kneel-sit-national-anthem&date=2017-09-27|archivedate=September 27, 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref> Many players, coaches and NFL teams protested and/or issued statements expressing dismay with Trump's comments:<ref name="ESPN.com">{{Cite news|url=http://www.espn.com/blog/nflnation/post/_/id/249755/nfl-players-who-protested-during-the-national-anthem-in-week-3|title=NFL players who protested during the national anthem in Week 3|publisher=ESPN|access-date=September 24, 2017}}</ref> * Twenty-seven members of the [[Baltimore Ravens]] and [[Jacksonville Jaguars]] knelt during the American National Anthem at their game at [[Wembley Stadium]] in London.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2017/sep/24/donald-trump-defied-wembley-jaguars-ravens-nfl-kneel-anthem|title=Donald Trump defied at Wembley as Jaguars and Ravens kneel for anthem|last=Wembley|first=Sean Ingle at|date=September 24, 2017|work=The Guardian|access-date=September 25, 2017|issn=0261-3077}}</ref> Retired Ravens star and honorary Team Captain [[Ray Lewis]] knelt with members of his team.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/sports/ravens/ravens-insider/bs-sp-ravens-anthem-protest-20170924-story.html|title=Some Ravens and Jaguars take knee during national anthem in wake of comments by President Trump|last=Zrebiec|first=Jeff|work=The Baltimore Sun|access-date=September 25, 2017}}</ref> All of the players stood for the British national anthem "[[God Save the Queen]]" with many remaining in locked arms.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Sweeney|first=Don|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/news/nation-world/world/article175130091.html|title=NFL players in London kneel for the US national anthem but stand for the British one|work=The Miami Herald|date=September 24, 2017|access-date=September 25, 2017}}</ref> * Several members of the [[Philadelphia Eagles]] raised their fists during the anthem before their game against the [[New York Giants]]. Before the same game, various Giants players stood with arms locked while others knelt.<ref name="NYTimes">{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/24/sports/nfl-trump-anthem-protests.html |title=Tom Brady Joins Anthem Demonstration as N.F.L. Protests Trump Comments |last=Belson |first=Ken |last2=Manchester |first2=Sam |date=September 24, 2017 |website=The New York Times |access-date=September 24, 2017 |last3=Mather |first3=Victor}}</ref> * The [[Seattle Seahawks]] and the [[Tennessee Titans]] did not take the field during the playing of the anthem, staying in their locker rooms until it concluded. The players of the Seahawks released a statement saying, "We will not stand for the injustice that has plagued people of color in this country. Out of love for our country and in honor of the sacrifices made on our behalf, we unite to oppose those that would deny our most basic freedoms."<ref name="ESPN.com"/> [[Meghan Linsey]], the Nashville singer who performed the anthem, knelt when she completed the song.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.tennessean.com/story/sports/nfl/titans/2017/09/24/meghan-linsey-kneels-after-singing-national-anthem-titans-seahawks-game/698362001/|title=Meghan Linsey kneels after singing national anthem at Titans-Seahawks game|work=The Tennessean|access-date=September 25, 2017}}</ref> * Before the opening of their game against the [[Houston Texans]], various [[New England Patriots]] players and staff also expressed their concerns, including quarterback [[Tom Brady]] locking arms with [[Phillip Dorsett]], and head coach [[Bill Belichick]] crossing his arms in front of him. Sixteen members of the Patriots knelt during the anthem.<ref name=":0" /> Patriots owner [[Robert Kraft]] said he was disappointed at the tone in which Trump's comments were made.<ref name="NYTimes"/> * Several members of the [[Miami Dolphins]] wore "#IMWITHKAP" T-shirts on the field during the pregame warmup, in support of Kaepernick's actions.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/nfl/2017/09/24/donald-trump-nfl-player-protests-national-anthem-week-3-response/697609001/|title=NFL player protests sweep league after President Donald Trump's hostile remarks|work=USA Today|access-date=September 24, 2017}}</ref> The team locked arms during the anthem, with five members kneeling. The opposing team, the [[New York Jets]], also linked arms during the anthem.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/sports/nfl/miami-dolphins/article175171896.html|title=Why did Stills kneel Sunday? Because he felt Trump tried to 'scare' or 'intimidate' him|work=The Miami Herald|access-date=September 25, 2017}}</ref> * All [[Pittsburgh Steelers]] players except [[Alejandro Villanueva (American football)|Alejandro Villanueva]], who served as an [[United States Army Rangers|Army Ranger]], refused to leave the locker room during the anthem. On the sideline, the [[Chicago Bears]] players locked their arms while the anthem was performed.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://wgntv.com/2017/09/24/nfl-sunday-kicks-off-amid-beef-between-players-trump/|title=From Chicago to London, NFL players react to Trump's protest critiques|date=September 24, 2017|publisher=WGN-TV|access-date=September 25, 2017}}</ref> Villanueva has since expressed regret for his actions.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.journalnow.com/news/nation_world/villanueva-on-anthem-flap-it-wasn-t-me-stepping-forward/article_62177918-7571-5d91-9bbf-f2337ea908ef.html|title=Villanueva on anthem flap: 'It wasn't me stepping forward'|last=Press|first=Associated|work=Winston-Salem Journal|access-date=2017-10-09|language=en}}</ref> * The majority of the [[Oakland Raiders]] either sat or knelt during the anthem, with several members of the opposing [[Washington Redskins]] either kneeling or joining arms as well.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.si.com/nfl/2017/09/24/raiders-sit-during-national-anthem-they-couldnt-stay-locker-room|title=Most of the Raiders took a seat during national anthem|last=Rollins|first=Khadrice|work=Sports Illustrated|access-date=September 25, 2017}}</ref> * Thirty-two members of the [[Denver Broncos]] knelt during the anthem.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.denverpost.com/2017/09/24/von-miller-broncos-kneel-national-anthem/|title=Von Miller among 32 Broncos players who take a knee for national anthem|date=September 24, 2017|work=The Denver Post|access-date=September 25, 2017}}</ref> At least ten members of the [[Buffalo Bills]] also knelt during the anthem, while other team members locked arms.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.newyorkupstate.com/buffalo-bills/index.ssf/2017/09/buffalo_bills_national_anthem_protests_kneeling_racial_injustive_donald_trump.html|title=Buffalo Bills lock arms during national anthem in response to Donald Trump|publisher=NewYorkUpstate.com|access-date=September 25, 2017}}</ref> Running back [[LeSean McCoy]] said "My message to him (Trump) is, be a president, be respectful, man. You know, us Americans, we are together. Stop trying to divide us."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.pennlive.com/sports/index.ssf/2017/09/lesean_mccoy_says_donald_trump.html|title=LeSean McCoy says Donald Trump should 'be a president,' 'be respectful'|publisher=PennLive.com|access-date=September 25, 2017}}</ref> McCoy performed stretches during the national anthem. * The [[Dallas Cowboys]] and [[Arizona Cardinals]] players locked arms during the anthem, while everyone on the Cowboys, including owner and general manager [[Jerry Jones]], knelt before the anthem was played.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Archer|first1=Todd|last2=Weinfuss|first2=Josh|title=Cowboys, Cardinals lock arms for national anthem in show of unity|publisher=ESPN|date=September 26, 2017|url=http://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/id/20819786/dallas-cowboys-arizona-cardinals-lock-arms-monday-night-football-game|accessdate=September 26, 2017}}</ref> * The [[New Orleans Saints]] established a plan with their team prior to their game against the [[Miami Dolphins]] on how they will handle the national anthem before the game. Drew Brees stood and stated the thoughts of his team as a whole by tweeting "As a way to show respect to all, our #Saints team will kneel in solidarity prior to the national anthem & stand together during the anthem."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nola.com/saints/index.ssf/2017/09/saints_protest_national_anthem.html|title=Drew Brees: Saints plan to kneel before national anthem, stand during it on Sunday|publisher=2017 NOLA media group|accessdate=October 1, 2017}}</ref> * More than ten [[Indianapolis Colts]] and about 20 [[Cleveland Browns]] players knelt on one knee while the remaining players locked arms during the playing of "[[The Star-Spangled Banner]]" in [[Indianapolis, Indiana]]. The actions were met by boos from the crowd at [[Lucas Oil Stadium]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.theindychannel.com/sports/colts/colts-kneel-lock-arms-in-show-of-unity-against-donald-trumps-comments |title=Colts kneel, lock arms in show of unity against Donald Trump's comments |publisher=[[WRTV]] |date=September 24, 2017 |accessdate=October 20, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.espn.com/blog/nflnation/post/_/id/249755/nfl-players-who-protested-during-the-national-anthem-in-week-3 |title=NFL players who protested during the national anthem in Week 3 |publisher=[[ESPN]] |date=September 25, 2017 |accessdate=October 20, 2017}}</ref> Indiana is the home state of Vice President [[Mike Pence]], who weeks later intentionally walked out of a Colts game against the 49ers.<ref>{{cite news|last=Crawford|first=Dakota|title=What is cost for Mike Pence to leave the Colts-49ers game|url=https://www.indystar.com/story/sports/nfl/colts/2017/10/08/vice-president-mike-pences-quick-and-costly-exit-colts-49-ers-game/744668001/|newspaper=[[The Indianapolis Star]]|date=October 8, 2017|accessdate=June 5, 2018}}</ref>
On October 16, 2017 Colin Kaepernick filed a grievance for collusion against NFL owners. Instead of using the NFLPA, Kaepernick hired Mark Geragos to be his attorney.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/id/21035352/colin-kaepernick-files-grievance-nfl-owners-collusion|title=Kaepernick files grievance claiming collusion|work=ESPN.com|access-date=2018-09-28|language=en}}</ref> As of August 31, 2018, an arbitrator ruled that there is sufficient evidence that the case can continue.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/2018/08/31/643582437/colin-kaepernicks-grievance-against-nfl-moves-forward|title=Colin Kaepernick's Grievance Against NFL Moves Forward|work=NPR.org|access-date=2018-09-28|language=en}}</ref>
In Week 8 at Seattle, the majority of the Texans players knelt during the anthem after Houston owner [[Bob McNair]] had commented about having the "inmates running the prison" during a league owner meeting regarding the ongoing protest. McNair had apologized, stating that he was not referring to the players, but rather to the "relationship between the league office and team owners".<ref>{{cite news|last=Barshop|first=Sarah|title=Texans' Duane Brown on kneeling for anthem: Team felt sense of unity playing for each other|date=October 29, 2017|website=ESPN.com|url=http://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/id/21215907/majority-houston-texans-players-kneeled-linked-arms-national-anthem|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171030025608/http://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/id/21215907/majority-houston-texans-players-kneeled-linked-arms-national-anthem|archivedate=October 30, 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first1=Seth|last1=Wickersham|first2=Don|last2=Van Natta Jr.|title=Gaffes, TV ratings concerns dominated as NFL, players forged anthem peace|date=October 27, 2017|website=ESPN.com|url=http://www.espn.com/espn/otl/story/_/id/21170410/gaffes-tv-ratings-concerns-dominated-nfl-players-forged-anthem-peace-league-meetings|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171029050500/http://www.espn.com/espn/otl/story/_/id/21170410/gaffes-tv-ratings-concerns-dominated-nfl-players-forged-anthem-peace-league-meetings|archivedate=October 29, 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref> It was the first time a Texans player had knelt during the anthem.<ref>{{cite news|last=Wilson|first=Aaron|title=Texans' Duane Brown says Bob McNair meeting 'didn't go too well'|date=October 29, 2017|newspaper=Houston Chronicle|url=http://www.chron.com/sports/texans/article/Majority-of-Texans-kneel-for-national-anthem-12315599.php|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171030132035/http://www.chron.com/sports/texans/article/Majority-of-Texans-kneel-for-national-anthem-12315599.php|archivedate=October 30, 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref>
===2018 preseason=== On May 23, 2018, NFL Commissioner [[Roger Goodell]] and all NFL team owners except for two owners that abstained from voting in a show of hand voting process, approved a new policy requiring all players to stand during the national anthem or be given the option to stay in the locker room during the national anthem. The vote took place without consulting the NFLPA.<ref>{{cite news|last=Healy|first=John|title=NFL admits there was no official vote on national anthem policy, instead informal show of hands|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/sports/football/nfl-admits-no-official-vote-national-anthem-policy-article-1.4009450|newspaper=[[New York Daily News]]|date=May 25, 2018|accessdate=June 5, 2018}}</ref> Any players from all NFL teams who protest the anthem while on the field will become subject to discipline from the league. In addition, the teams as a whole will be subject to punishment and other forms of discipline from the NFL as a result.<ref>{{cite news|last=Knoblauch|first=Austin|title=NFL expected to enact national anthem policy for '18|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000933952/article/nfl-expected-to-enact-national-anthem-policy-for-18|publisher=NFL Enterprises, LLC|website=NFL.com|date=May 23, 2018|accessdate=May 23, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Roger Goodell's statement on national anthem policy|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000933962/article/roger-goodells-statement-on-national-anthem-policy|publisher=NFL Enterprises, LLC|website=NFL.com|date=May 23, 2018|accessdate=May 23, 2018}}</ref>
In disagreement with the policy, several players on the Super Bowl champion [[Philadelphia Eagles]] indicated they would decline an invitation from Trump to visit the [[White House]] on June 5, leading the President to rescind the offer the day before the event.<ref>{{cite news|title=Donald Trump calls off Eagles' White House visit over national anthem dispute|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/donald-trump-calls-off-eagles-white-house-visit-players-decline-invitation-232323202.html|publisher=Oath Inc. (Verizon)|website=Yahoo Sports|date=June 4, 2018|accessdate=June 5, 2018}}</ref> The Eagles were the second sports franchise that Trump had uninvited, joining the 2017 [[National Basketball Association]] (NBA) champion [[Golden State Warriors]], whose visit was cancelled after several players publicly declined to attend.<ref>{{cite news|title='Fragile egomaniac': Philly Mayor responds to Trump's White House snub|date=June 5, 2018|work=Fox Sports|url=https://www.foxsports.com.au/nfl/donald-trump-cancels-the-philadelphia-eagles-visit-to-the-white-house/news-story/e6a2b3c5b5ee2a9f7f0a8b42633e0706|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180718112114/https://www.foxsports.com.au/nfl/donald-trump-cancels-the-philadelphia-eagles-visit-to-the-white-house/news-story/e6a2b3c5b5ee2a9f7f0a8b42633e0706|archivedate=July 18, 2018|deadurl=no}}</ref>
On July 19, the NFL and the players association issued a joint statement that "no rules relating to the anthem will be issued for the next several weeks." This came after the [[Associated Press]] had reported earlier in the day that Miami team rules stated that improper anthem conduct could result in a player suspension of up to four games, more than some players receive for violating the [[NFL domestic violence policy|league's domestic violence policy]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Orr|first=Connor|title=The Five Hours That Forced the NFL to Reconsider Its Anthem Policy|date=July 20, 2018|website=SI.com|url=https://www.si.com/nfl/2018/07/19/miami-dolphins-national-anthem-policy-rule-nfl-training-camp|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180721123241/https://www.si.com/nfl/2018/07/19/miami-dolphins-national-anthem-policy-rule-nfl-training-camp|archivedate=July 21, 2018}}</ref> The following day, Trump tweeted that players should be suspended for one game the first time kneeling, and for the entire season without pay after a second offense.<ref>{{cite news|last=West|first=Jenna|title=Donald Trump Suggests Players Kneeling for Anthem Should Be Suspended for Entire Season|date=July 20, 2018|website=SI.com|url=https://www.si.com/nfl/2018/07/20/donald-trump-national-anthem-policy-players-kneel-no-pay-suspended|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180721105831/https://www.si.com/nfl/2018/07/20/donald-trump-national-anthem-policy-players-kneel-no-pay-suspended|archivedate=July 21, 2018|deadurl=no}}</ref>
==Other athletes join==
===Soccer=== [[File:Megan_Rapinoe_USA_vs_Can_Sep17.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Megan Rapinoe]] in 2011]] [[Seattle Reign FC]] and [[United States women's national soccer team|U.S. women's national soccer team]] player [[Megan Rapinoe]] knelt during the national anthem in a game on September 5, 2016, explaining that her decision was a "nod to Kaepernick and everything that he's standing for right now".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2016/09/05/sport/megan-rapinoe-colin-kaepernick-anthem-kneel/index.html|title=Megan Rapinoe takes knee in solidarity with Kaepernick|last=McKirdy|first=Euan|date=September 5, 2016|publisher=CNN|access-date=September 7, 2016}}</ref> In a subsequent match at the [[Washington Spirit]], Spirit owner Bill Lynch – anticipating Rapinoe's protest – moved the national anthem's performance without warning or notice to occur before the players' appearances on the pitch. [[Jeff Plush]], the league's commissioner, was present at the game and told reporters that he was unaware of Lynch's plans and disagreed with the act of moving the anthem's performance.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/soccer-insider/wp/2016/09/07/megan-rapinoe-doesnt-get-chance-to-kneel-for-national-anthem-it-was-played-with-teams-in-locker-room/?tid=a_inl|title=Megan Rapinoe doesn't get chance to kneel for national anthem. It was played with teams in locker room.|date=September 7, 2016|access-date=November 1, 2016|work=The Washington Post|author=Steven Goff}}</ref> The Spirit's players issued a joint statement also disagreeing with Lynch's decision to move the anthem without first consulting the team's players or coaches.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/soccer-insider/wp/2016/09/09/washington-spirit-players-unhappy-with-owners-anthem-move/|title=Washington Spirit players unhappy with owner's anthem move|author=Steven Goff|work=The Washington Post|date=September 9, 2016|access-date=November 1, 2016}}</ref>
As a member of the U.S. women's national soccer team, Rapinoe also knelt before an international [[Exhibition game|friendly match]] against [[Thailand women's national football team|Thailand]] on September 16, despite public statements of disagreement with her protest methods issued before the match by the [[U.S. Soccer Federation]] and her coach [[Jill Ellis]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.si.com/planet-futbol/2016/09/15/megan-rapinoe-uswnt-thailand-national-anthem-kneels|title=USWNT's Megan Rapinoe kneels for national anthem before Thailand match|work=[[Sports Illustrated]]|date=September 19, 2016|access-date=November 1, 2016}}</ref> U.S. Soccer proceeded to pass a policy that now requires all of its players to stand "respectfully" during the national anthem making it the first American sports league or governing body to do so.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.sbnation.com/soccer/2017/3/6/14825652/united-states-soccer-national-anthem-policy-megan-rapinoe-protest-ban|title=U.S. Soccer banned Megan Rapinoe's national anthem protest without caring to understand it|work=SBNation.com|access-date=2017-10-11}}</ref>
[[Major League Soccer]] (MLS) have released a statement in September 2017 regarding any potential protests "The march of players, officials and children into our stadiums and singing of the anthem has been a pre-match tradition since our first game in 1996. The National Anthem provides our clubs and fans an important and time-honored opportunity to salute our country and stand up for its principles -- whether in the United States or in Canada."<ref name="ReferenceA">http://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/id/20848575/rules-national-anthem-differ-sports-leagues</ref> MLS to date, has yet to encounter national anthem protests.
The protest had supporters outside the U.S. as well: In an October 2017 match against [[Schalke 04]], players and staff of German football club [[Hertha BSC]] took the knee in solidarity.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.si.com/soccer/2017/10/14/hertha-berlin-kneel-german-national-anthem-protest|title=Hertha Berlin players take knee during German anthem|last=Rapaport|first=Daniel|date=October 14, 2017|work=Sports Illustrated}}</ref> Herta BSC has a few American players on their roster.
===College=== On September 7, 2016, three volleyball players from [[West Virginia University Institute of Technology|West Virginia Tech]] knelt during the national anthem.<ref name="kalea">{{cite web|last1=Gunderson|first1=Kalea|title=West Virginia Tech volleyball players kneel during national anthem|url=http://wchstv.com/news/local/west-virginia-tech-volleyball-players-kneel-during-national-anthem|date=September 7, 2016|publisher=ABC|accessdate=September 21, 2016}}</ref><ref name="gibbs"/>
On October 1, at [[East Carolina University]], about 19 members of the band knelt, while about another two held the American flag during the national anthem at the beginning of the football game against the [[University of Central Florida]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.witn.com/content/news/395523401.html |title=ECU chancellor, Gov. McCrory speak out about band members kneeling |publisher=WITN-TV |accessdate=November 8, 2016}}</ref> There have been almost no such incidents involving college football players, for the simple reason that college players and coaches are typically in the locker room when the anthem is played. There has been at least one exception to the rule, however. During a September 2016 away game at [[Northwestern Wildcats football|Northwestern]], where players are traditionally on the field during the anthem, three [[Nebraska Cornhuskers football|Nebraska]] players knelt on the sideline.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sbnation.com/college-football/2017/9/26/16354940/protests-college-football-nfl-national-anthem|title=Why protests aren't as common in college football|last=Kirshner|first=Alex|date=September 28, 2017|publisher=SB Nation}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://journalstar.com/sports/huskers/football/prior-to-game-rose-ivey-told-team-of-his-decision/article_781e987e-82b0-11e6-93cc-53559523f8fe.html|title=Prior to game, Rose-Ivey told team of his decision to kneel for anthem|last=Christopherson|first=Brian|date=|work=Lincoln Journal Star}}</ref> The NCAA football rulebook does not address the issue of pregame ceremonies (patriotic or otherwise) at all, except to say that team captains must be present for a [[coin toss]] three minutes before the first-half kickoff.
[[College of the Ozarks]] president Jerry Davis announced in September 2017 that his college's teams would [[Forfeit (sport)|refuse to play]] any team whose players knelt during the anthem.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.news-leader.com/story/news/education/2017/09/29/no-pledge-no-play-policy-college-ozarks-student-athletes/717937001/|title=If you kneel, the game is over, C of O tells opposing teams|last=Riley|first=Claudette|date=September 29, 2017|work=Springfield News-Leader}}</ref> In response, the [[National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics|NAIA]] chose to move its [[NAIA Men's Basketball Championships#Division II|Division II men's basketball champion game]] away from College of the Ozarks' [[Keeter Gymnasium]] (where the championship game had been held since 2000) to [[Sanford Pentagon]], [[South Dakota]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.news-leader.com/story/sports/college/2017/10/27/anthem-protest-policy-moves-naia-basketball-tournament-away-college-ozarks/807857001/|title=Anthem protest policy moves NAIA basketball tournament away from College of the Ozarks|date=October 27, 2017|work=Springfield News-Leader}}</ref>
===High school=== On September 2, 2016, a football player at [[Brunswick High School (Ohio)|Brunswick High School]] in [[Ohio]] knelt during the national anthem after he heard his teammates saying "[[nigger]]".<ref name="gibbs">{{cite web|last1=Gibbs|first1=Lindsay|title=Tracking the Kaepernick Effect: The anthem protests are spreading|url=https://thinkprogress.org/national-anthem-sports-protest-tracker-kaepernick-284ff1d1ab3e#.c5u4c1quw|publisher=think progress|accessdate=September 21, 2016}}</ref> After his protest, the player received racial threats.<ref name="fox">{{cite web|last1=Freeman|first1=Kevin|title=First home game for Brunswick High School since player said he received racial threats|url=http://fox8.com/2016/09/16/first-home-game-for-brunswick-high-school-since-player-said-he-received-racial-threats/|publisher=Fox|accessdate=September 21, 2016}}</ref> On September 9, high school players across the country knelt during the national anthem. On September 23, four players from [[Withrow High School]], three black and one white, in [[Cincinnati]] knelt during the national anthem before their football game.<ref name="gibbs"/>
In September 2017, Principal Waylon Bates of [[Parkway High School (Louisiana)|Parkway High School]] in [[Louisiana]] referred to the national anthem protests as a "disruption" and threatened to kick any player out of the football team if he knelt during the national anthem.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/early-lead/wp/2017/09/28/louisiana-high-school-will-kick-students-off-team-if-they-dont-stand-for-national-anthem/|title=Louisiana high school will kick students off team if they don't stand for national anthem|first=Jacob|last=Bogage|date=September 28, 2017|publisher=|accessdate=October 4, 2017|via=www.washingtonpost.com}}</ref> Two black students on the Victory & Praise Christian Academy football team protested during the anthem. Immediately after the anthem concluded, their coach removed them from the team, having them take off their uniforms on the [[sidelines]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sfgate.com/sports/highschool/article/High-school-football-kicked-off-team-anthem-kneel-12242713.php|title=Local high school football players kicked off team after protest during anthem|website=sfgate.com|accessdate=October 4, 2017}}</ref>
===Baseball=== On September 23, 2017, [[Bruce Maxwell]] of the [[Oakland Athletics]] knelt during the national anthem, becoming the first MLB player to join the protest. His team backed him up by saying, "The Oakland A's pride ourselves on being inclusive. We respect and support all of our players' constitutional rights and freedom of expression."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sfgate.com/athletics/article/A-s-Bruce-Maxwell-first-MLB-player-to-kneel-for-12223798.php|title=A's Bruce Maxwell first MLB player to kneel for anthem}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/trump-baseball-first-take-national-anthem_us_59c7051ae4b01cc57ff2a61e|title=MLB's First Player Just Took A Knee During The National Anthem|last=Madani|first=Doha|date=September 24, 2017|work=HuffPost|access-date=September 24, 2017}}</ref> Maxwell received a standing ovation from A's fans before his first at-bat following his protest.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.sbnation.com/mlb/2017/9/25/16364924/bruce-maxwell-standing-ovation-protest-fans-oakland|title=In his first at-bat after taking a knee, Bruce Maxwell got a standing ovation from fans|work=SBNation.com|access-date=September 26, 2017}}</ref>
The MLB has no policy regarding the national anthem other than it has to be played before games.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
===Basketball=== On September 24, 2017, prior to Game 1 of the [[2017 WNBA Finals]], players from the [[Los Angeles Sparks]] chose to stay in the locker room during the national anthem, while members of the [[Minnesota Lynx]] locked arms on the court.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://deadspin.com/los-angeles-sparks-leave-court-before-national-anthem-i-1818709276|title=Los Angeles Sparks Leave Court Before National Anthem in Game 1 of WNBA Finals|last=Theisen|first=Lauren|date=September 24, 2017|work=Deadspin|access-date=September 24, 2017}}</ref>
The [[NBA]] has a policy that requires players to stand up during the national anthem in their CBA, however many prominent players have expressed support for the NFL protests on social media or in interviews.<ref>https://www.bostonglobe.com/sports/celtics/2018/06/04/why-don-players-have-problem-with-nba-national-anthem-policy/RDqhgKaScJL2DPLLSuWiVM/story.html</ref>
===Ice hockey=== On October 7, 2017, [[J. T. Brown (ice hockey)|J. T. Brown]] of the [[Tampa Bay Lightning]] raised his fist while standing on the bench during the national anthem. He had also done the same in a preseason game, in an attempt to "bring awareness to police brutality against minorities and racial inequality".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tampabay.com/sports/hockey/lightning/lightnings-jt-brown-raises-fist-in-protest-during-anthem-before-panthers/2340305|title=Lightning's J.T. Brown raises fist in protest during anthem before Panthers game|last=Smith|first=Joe|date=October 7, 2017|work=tampabay.com|publisher=Tampa Bay Times|accessdate=October 7, 2017}}</ref> He stated that he had "received death threats" after the protest.<ref name=thescore>{{cite web|url=https://www.thescore.com/nhl/news/1393535-lightning-s-brown-i-have-received-death-threats-after-protest|title=Lightning's Brown: 'I have received death threats' after protest|last=Livingstone|first=Flip|date=October 8, 2017|work=[[TheScore Inc.|TheScore.com]]|publisher=Score Media Ventures Inc.|accessdate=October 8, 2017}}</ref>
==Reactions==
===Political figures=== [[File:Mike Pence NFL Protests 2017.jpg|thumb|Vice President Pence stands for anthem prior to leaving after players knelt]] In September 2016, President [[Barack Obama]] stated that Kaepernick was "exercising his constitutional right" to protest. He went on: "I don't doubt his sincerity. I think he cares about some real, legitimate issues that have to be talked about. If nothing else, he's generated more conversation about issues that have to be talked about."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Hjelmgaard|first1=Kim|title=24095 924 494 Obama defends Kaepernick's national anthem protest|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/nfl/2016/09/05/obama-defends-kaepernicks-national-anthem-protest/89879478/|work=USA Today|accessdate=September 20, 2016}}</ref>
[[U.S. Supreme Court|Supreme Court]] Justice [[Ruth Bader Ginsburg]] criticized the protest as "dumb and disrespectful", stating that athletes have the right to protest "if they want to be stupid". The Supreme Court later issued a statement from Ginsburg stating that her comments were "inappropriately dismissive and harsh. I should have declined to respond."<ref>{{cite web|title=Ruth Bader Ginsburg apologizes for criticizing anthem protests|url=http://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/id/17795159/ruth-bader-ginsburg-apologizes-criticizing-colin-kaepernick-anthem-protest|publisher=ESPN|accessdate=October 14, 2016}}</ref>
On September 25, 2017, [[U.S. Representative]] [[Sheila Jackson Lee]] knelt on the floor of the House of Representatives.<ref>{{cite web|last=Chason |first=Rachel |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2017/09/26/that-is-racism-black-lawmaker-condemns-trump-kneels-in-congress-to-honor-nfl-players/ |title='That is racism': Black lawmaker condemns Trump, kneels in Congress to honor NFL players |publisher=The Washington Post |date= |accessdate=September 28, 2017}}</ref> Fellow congressman [[Mark Pocan]] knelt on the floor of the House the next day.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thehill.com/blogs/floor-action/house/352448-another-democrat-takes-a-knee-on-house-floor-to-support-nfl-protests |title=Another Democrat takes a knee on House floor to support NFL protests |publisher=TheHill |date= |accessdate=September 28, 2017}}</ref>
On September 26, 2017, Louisiana Lt. Gov. [[Billy Nungesser]] told [[The Times-Picayune]] that he would not be attending the [[New Orleans Saints]] game against the [[Miami Dolphins]], which was going to be taking place in London. Although he was going to be in London during the time of the game, he told the newspaper that he would not attend because he was "disappointed in the NFL." He added that "it is disgraceful that anybody would use that as a time to protest."<ref>{{cite web |last1=Seraaj |first1=Intisar |last2=Zdanowicz |first2=Christina |title="From Jersey burnings to players being uninvited, backlash to the #TakeAKnee protest grows" |url=https://www.cnn.com/2017/09/25/us/anthem-protests-burning-nfl-jerseys-trnd/index.html |website=CNN |accessdate=28 September 2018}}</ref>
On October 8, 2017, [[United States Vice President|Vice President]] [[Mike Pence]] left a game between the NFL's [[Indianapolis Colts]] and the San Francisco 49ers, members of which had knelt during the anthem, "because President Trump and I will not dignify any event that disrespects our soldiers, our Flag, or our National Anthem."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/10/08/556531518/vp-pence-takes-a-stand-and-walks-away-after-nfl-players-kneel|title=Trump Defends Pence's NFL Protest Amid Claims It Was A Publicity Stunt|last=Romo|first=Vanessa|publisher=NPR|date=October 8, 2017|accessdate=October 8, 2017}}</ref>
[[Oklahoma]] senator [[James Lankford]] said [[Trolls from Olgino|Russian internet trolls]], seeking to polarize Americans, helped fuel a debate.<ref>{{cite web|author=Devlin Barrett|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/lawmaker-russian-trolls-trying-to-sow-discord-in-nfl-kneeling-debate/2017/09/27/5f46dce0-a3b0-11e7-ade1-76d061d56efa_story.html|title=Lawmaker: Russian trolls trying to sow discord in NFL kneeling debate|publisher=washingtonpost.com|date=September 27, 2017|accessdate=December 1, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/russian-trolls-using-nfl-protests-sow-discord-online-republican-senator-n805296|title=Russian trolls using NFL protests to sow discord online, GOP senator says|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/russian-internet-trolls-calling-takeaknee-boycottnf-sow-discord/story?id=50132807|title=Russian internet trolls pushed national anthem controversy, #TakeAKnee: Senator|first=A. B. C.|last=News|date=September 27, 2017|website=ABC News}}</ref>
<blockquote>We watched, even this weekend, the Russians and their troll farms, their internet folks, start hashtagging out #TakeAKnee and also hashtagging out #BoycottNFL," he said during a hearing on threats faced by the United States. "They were taking both sides of the argument this weekend ... to try to raise the noise level of America and make a big issue seem like an even bigger issue as they are trying to push divisiveness in this country."</blockquote>
===Corporations=== Major sports sponsors [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]], [[Under Armour]], and [[Ford]] all issued statements in support of athletes' freedom of expression after Trump's comments regarding the NFL. Nike's statement read, "Nike supports athletes and their right to freedom of expression on issues that are of great importance to our society."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/nike-becomes-first-nfl-sponsor-take-side-trump-vs-nfl-193639102.html|title=Nike, an NFL sponsor, takes clear side in Trump vs NFL|access-date=2017-09-28|language=en-US}}</ref> In September 2016, after [[Brandon Marshall (linebacker)|Brandon Marshall]] knelt during the national anthem, [[Century Link]] and [[Air Academy Federal Credit Union]] dropped him as a paid sponsor.<ref name="crab">{{cite web|last1=Crabtree|first1=Curtis|title=Brandon Marshall picks up new endorsement after losing two following anthem kneel|url=http://profootballtalk.nbcsports.com/2016/09/15/brandon-marshall-picks-up-new-endorsement-after-losing-two-following-anthem-kneel/|publisher=NBC Sports|accessdate=September 21, 2016}}</ref> Radio station [[WFAY]] dropped a broadcast of an [[East Carolina University]] football game on the station after the marching band took part in the protest, calling it an insult to the U.S. Armed Forces.<ref>Martin, Nick (October 6, 2016). [http://deadspin.com/local-espn-radio-station-to-drop-ecu-game-after-band-pr-1787404764 Local ESPN Radio Station To Drop ECU Game After Band Protest]. ''Deadspin''. Retrieved October 6, 2016.</ref> [[John Schnatter]] of sponsor [[Papa John's Pizza]] blamed the protests for a drop in sales and a 24% fall in stock during 2017, saying that the "controversy is polarizing the customer, polarizing the country".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://money.cnn.com/2017/11/01/media/nfl-papa-johns-protests/index.html|title=Papa John's says NFL protests are hurting sales|last=Meyersohn|first=Nathaniel|date=November 1, 2017|access-date=November 2, 2017|work=CNN Money}}</ref> Later that day, the company announced that the NFL shield or "official sponsor" designation on Papa John's commercials and advertising would be removed.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/id/21250448/nfl-sponsor-papa-john-not-happy-anthem-protests|title=Papa John's says anthem protests are hurting deal with NFL|first=Darren|last=Rovell|work=ESPN.com|date=November 1, 2017|accessdate=November 2, 2017}}</ref> In December 2017 [[Sanderson Farms]] CEO questioned whether the NFL protests were to blame for falling [[Buffalo wing|chicken wing]] prices.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-12-14/nfl-player-protests-hurting-chicken-wing-sales-producer-says|title=Chicken Wing Company Says NFL Player Protests Are Hurting Sales|first=Megan|last=Durisin|work=Bloomberg.com|date=December 15, 2017|accessdate=January 18, 2018}}</ref>
After his first kneel in 2016, Nike was well on its way to sever its four year long partnership with NFL quarterback Colin Kaepernick.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/09/26/sports/nike-colin-kaepernick.html|title=Nike Nearly Dropped Colin Kaepernick Before Embracing Him|access-date=2018-09-28|language=en}}</ref> Nigel Powell, chief communications executive of Nike, convinced the company to maintain their partnership with Kaepernick which eventually led to the launch of the politically and socially controversial advertisement released in 2018, "Nike - Dream Crazy", with Kaepernick as their face of the campaign.<ref>{{Citation|last=Nike|title=Nike - Dream Crazy|date=2018-09-05|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Fq2CvmgoO7I|access-date=2018-09-28}}</ref> Despite the prevalent backlash on social media of people who criticized Kaepernick's actions burning and cutting up their Nike brand clothing, Nike sales increased by 31% within five days after the advertisement was released. This campaign did result in a temporary drop of 2.2% in stock price though.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://time.com/5390884/nike-sales-go-up-kaepernick-ad/|title=Nike Sales Increase 31% After Kaepernick Ad Despite Backlash|website=Time|language=en|access-date=2018-09-28}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/09/19/nike-colin-kaepernick-ads-national-anthem-protest-controversy.html|title=Some people may hate Nike's marketing campaigns—but the brand keeps adding billions to its bottom line|last=Turner|first=Dymond Green, Ashley|date=2018-09-19|work=CNBC|access-date=2018-09-27}}</ref>
===Athletes and sports media=== Throughout the remainder of the 2016 season, Kaepernick received public backlash for his protest, with an anonymous [[NFL]] executive calling Kaepernick "a traitor".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/2651681-mike-freemans-10-point-stance-kaepernick-anger-intense-in-nfl-front-offices|title=Kaepernick Anger Intense in NFL Front Offices|first=Mike|last=Freeman|accessdate=September 8, 2016}}</ref> He also stated that he received death threats.<ref name="deaththreats">[http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2016/09/nfl-kaepernick-received-death-threats-160921152934415.html US: Colin Kaepernick says he has received death threats]. [[Al Jazeera]]. September 22, 2016.</ref>
Sportscaster [[Bob Costas]] offered support for Kaepernick stating, "Patriotism comes in many forms and what has happened is it's been conflated with a bumper-style kind of flag-waving and with the military only so that people cannot see that in his own way Colin Kaepernick, however imperfectly, is doing a patriotic thing."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://ftw.usatoday.com/2017/09/bob-costas-trump-nfl|title=Bob Costas puts the entire national anthem debate in perspective with one powerful segment|date=September 25, 2017|work=For The Win|access-date=September 25, 2017}}</ref>
[[Trent Dilfer]] criticized Kaepernick. "The big thing that hit me through all this was this is a backup quarterback whose job is to be quiet, and sit in the shadows and get the starter ready to play Week 1," Dilfer said on ''[[Sunday NFL Countdown]]''. "Yet he chose a time where all of a sudden he became the center of attention. And it has disrupted that organization. It has caused friction. And it's torn at the fabric of the team."<ref name="mercury">{{cite news|last1=Inman|first1=Cam|title=Colin Kaepernick told by ESPN's Trent Dilfer to 'be quiet, sit in the shadows'|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/2016/09/11/colin-kaepernick-told-by-espns-trent-dilfer-to-be-quiet-sit-in-the-shadows/|website=The Mercury News|accessdate=September 21, 2016}}</ref>
Stemming from the Kaepernick controversy, before the beginning of the [[2016 World Cup of Hockey]] tournament in [[Toronto|Toronto, Canada]], Team USA coach [[John Tortorella]] told in an interview that if any one of his players were to sit out during the anthem, they would sit on the bench for the entire duration of the game.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.sportsnet.ca/hockey/world-cup-of-hockey/tortorella-will-sit-anthem-protests-team-usa/|title=Tortorella 'will sit' any Team USA player who protests anthem - Sportsnet.ca|newspaper=Sportsnet.ca|access-date=2017-02-12|language=en-US}}</ref>
The September 2016 police shootings of [[Shooting of Terence Crutcher|Terence Crutcher]] and [[Shooting of Keith Lamont Scott|Keith Lamont Scott]] bolstered support for his protest.<ref>{{cite news|last=Maxwell|first=Francis|title=Silence From Kaepernick Critics Speaks Volumes|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/57e2f47fe4b05d3737be53de?timestamp=1474507429354|website=[[HuffPost]]|date=September 21, 2016|accessdate=June 5, 2018}}</ref> Kaepernick said of the Terence Crutcher shooting, "this is a perfect example of what this is about."<ref name="deaththreats"/> Boxer [[Floyd Mayweather]], criticized Kaepernick, stating, "You know, a lot of times, we get stuck, and we are followers. When you hear one person say 'black lives matter' or 'blue lives matter,' all lives matter." Adding moments later, "With me being a fighter, and my hands being registered, if I hit a guy for breaking in my house, or breaking in my car, it's gonna cost me more money, so I gotta work smarter, not harder. I'm gonna call the cops."<ref>{{cite news|last=Payne|first=Marissa|title=Floyd Mayweather advises people to 'follow order' because 'all lives matter'|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/early-lead/wp/2016/10/11/floyd-mayweather-advises-people-to-follow-order-because-all-lives-matter/|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 11, 2016|accessdate=June 5, 2018}}</ref>
Discussion continued throughout August 2017. [[National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum|Baseball Hall of Famer]] Hank Aaron said, "I think he's getting a raw deal" from the NFL.<ref>{{cite news|last=Axisa|first=Mike|title=MLB Hall of Famer Hank Aaron says Colin Kaepernick is 'getting a raw deal' from NFL|url=https://www.cbssports.com/mlb/news/mlb-hall-of-famer-hank-aaron-says-colin-kaepernick-is-getting-a-raw-deal-from-nfl/|publisher=CBS Sports|website=CBSSports.com|date=August 26, 2017|accessdate=June 5, 2018}}</ref> That same month, [[Pro Football Hall of Fame]]r and longtime [[Civil and political rights|civil rights activist]] [[Jim Brown]], who a year earlier supported Kaepernick "100 percent",<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000692374/article/jim-brown-im-with-colin-kaepernick-100-percent|title=Jim Brown: I'm with Colin Kaepernick '100 percent'|publisher=National Football League|date=August 29, 2016}}</ref> now criticized him, suggesting Kaepernick ought to decide whether to be an athlete or an activist.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/early-lead/wp/2017/08/25/jim-brown-says-i-dont-desecrate-my-flag-thinks-colin-kaepernick-should-pick-football-or-activism/|title=Jim Brown says 'I don't desecrate my flag,' thinks Colin Kaepernick should pick football or activism|website=The Washington Post|access-date=August 26, 2017}}</ref> "I'm an American," said Brown. "I don't desecrate my flag and my national anthem. … This is my country, and I'll work out the problems, but I'll do it in an intelligent manner."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/nfl/2017/08/25/jim-brown-colin-kaepernick-i-dont-desecrate-my-flag-and-my-national-anthem/602349001/|title=Jim Brown on Colin Kaepernick: 'I don't desecrate my flag and my national anthem'|date=August 25, 2017|website=USA Today|accessdate=August 25, 2017}}</ref>
[[Jim Harbaugh]], Kaepernick's former coach, penned a strong statement of support for him as part of ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]''{{'}}s "[[Time 100|100 Most Influential People]]" series. Harbaugh wrote, "His willingness to take a position at personal cost is now part of our American story. How lucky for us all and for our country to have among our citizens someone as remarkable as Colin Kaepernick."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://time.com/collection/2017-time-100/4736257/colin-kaepernick/|title=Colin Kaepernick: The World's 100 Most Influential People|website=Time|access-date=September 25, 2017}}</ref>
[[NASCAR]] team owners [[Richard Petty]] and [[Richard Childress]] have supported Trump and said that they would fire drivers and employees who would not stand for the national anthem.<ref>{{cite news|last=Parco|first=Nicholas|title=NASCAR owners threaten to fire any drivers who kneel during national anthem|work=Daily News|location=New York|date=September 24, 2017|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/sports/more-sports/nascar-owners-threaten-fire-drivers-protest-anthem-article-1.3518424|accessdate=September 24, 2017}}</ref> Petty said, "Anybody that don't stand up for the anthem ought to be out of the country. Period." Childress said, "It'll get you a ride on a Greyhound bus" if anyone on his team protested the anthem.<ref>{{cite news | last2=Hamilton | last1=Bieler | first2=Tracee | first1=Des | title=Richard Petty, other NASCAR owners decry protests, but Dale Earnhardt Jr. offers support | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/early-lead/wp/2017/09/24/richard-petty-among-nascar-owners-saying-anthem-protests-will-get-employees-fired/ | work=Washington Post | date=September 25, 2017 | accessdate=September 26, 2017}}</ref> Driver [[Dale Earnhardt Jr.]], however, expressed support for the peaceful protests, quoting President [[John F. Kennedy]], "Those who make peaceful revolution impossible will make violent revolution inevitable."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cbssports.com/general/news/nascars-dale-earnhardt-jr-voices-support-for-peaceful-protests-in-america/|title=NASCAR's Dale Earnhardt Jr. voices support for peaceful protests in America|publisher=CBSSports.com|access-date=September 25, 2017}}</ref> NASCAR released a statement on September 25 in response to the protests that said, "Sports are a unifying influence in our society, bringing people of differing backgrounds and beliefs together. Our respect for the national anthem has always been a hallmark of our pre-race events. Thanks to the sacrifices of many, we live in a country of unparalleled freedoms and countless liberties, including the right to peacefully express one's opinion."<ref>{{cite web|title=NASCAR statement|publisher=NASCAR.com|date=September 25, 2017|url=https://www.nascar.com/news-media/2017/09/25/nascar-statement-september-25/|accessdate=September 26, 2017}}</ref>
[[Jemele Hill]], an ESPN anchor who called Trump a "white supremacist" in a series of tweets earlier in the month, tweeted, "Just so we're clear: the president's comments will only incite more player protests, not quell them." following Trump's initial response to the protests.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://money.cnn.com/2017/09/13/media/jemele-hill-espn-white-house/index.html|title=ESPN says it accepts Jemele Hill's apology after anti-Trump tweets|publisher=CNN|date=September 14, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://thehill.com/homenews/media/352026-espns-jemele-hill-trumps-nfl-remarks-will-only-make-more-players-protest|title=ESPN's Jemele Hill: Trump's NFL remarks will only make more players protest|publisher=The Hill|date=September 9, 2017}}</ref> Hill was later put on a two-week suspension for "a second violation of our social media guidelines", after Hill suggested people direct their disagreements towards advertisers of Dallas Cowboys owner, [[Jerry Jones]], after Jones stated he would bench any player who protested the national anthem on October 9, 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/id/20961541/dallas-cowboys-owner-jerry-jones-says-player-disrespects-flag-play|title=Jerry Jones: Cowboys will bench any player who 'disrespects' flag|publisher=ESPN|date=October 9, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://money.cnn.com/2017/10/09/media/jemele-hill-espn-suspended/index.html|title=ESPN suspends Jemele Hill over tweets|publisher=CNNMoney|date=October 9, 2017}}</ref>
On September 25, 2017, [[Bill Russell]] posted a photo to Twitter while kneeling and wearing his [[Presidential Medal of Freedom]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://whdh.com/news/celtics-legend-bill-russell-takes-knee-in-photo-with-presidential-medal-of-freedom/ |title=Celtics legend Bill Russell takes knee in photo with Presidential Medal of Freedom |publisher=WHDH 7News |date=February 13, 2011 |accessdate=September 28, 2017}}</ref> On September 26, 2017, Joey Odoms, the national anthem singer for the home games of the Ravens, resigned citing the "tone/actions of a large number of NFL fans in the midst of our country's cultural crisis".<ref>{{cite news |last1=Zrebiec |first1=Jeff |title=Ravens national anthem singer Joey Odoms, a combat veteran, informs team he is resigning |url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/sports/ravens/ravens-insider/bs-sp-odoms-resigning-20170926-story.html |accessdate=September 27, 2017 |work=The Baltimore Sun |date=September 26, 2017}}</ref>
Former [[Chicago Bears]] coach [[Mike Ditka]] commented, "If you don't respect our country, then you shouldn't be in this country playing football…So I would say, adios." He added that he was "not condemning anybody or criticizing anybody" in his remarks. According to Ditka, "there has been no oppression in the last 100 years that I know of."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/sports/mike-ditka-nfl-protests-there-s-been-no-oppression-u-n809566|title=Mike Ditka on NFL Protests: There's Been No Oppression in U.S. in Last 100 Years|publisher=NBC News|date=October 10, 2017}}</ref>
